006import squidpony.squidgrid.zone.MutableZone;

009import java.io.Serializable;
010import java.util.*;

012import static squidpony.squidmath.CrossHash.Water.*;

014/**
015 * Region encoding of on/off information about areas using bitsets; uncompressed (fatty), but fast (greased lightning).
016 * This can handle any size of 2D data, and is not strictly limited to 256x256 as CoordPacker is. It stores several long
017 * arrays and uses each bit in one of those numbers to represent a single point, though sometimes this does waste bits
018 * if the height of the area this encodes is not a multiple of 64 (if you store a 80x64 map, this uses 80 longs; if you
019 * store an 80x65 map, this uses 160 longs, 80 for the first 64 rows and 80 more to store the next row). It's much
020 * faster than CoordPacker at certain operations (anything that expands or retracts an area, including
021 * {@link #expand()}), {@link #retract()}), {@link #fringe()}), {@link #surface()}, and {@link #flood(GreasedRegion)},
022 * and slightly faster on others, like {@link #and(GreasedRegion)} (called intersectPacked() in CoordPacker) and
023 * {@link #or(GreasedRegion)} (called unionPacked() in CoordPacker).
024 * <br>
025 * Each GreasedRegion is mutable, and instance methods typically modify that instance and return it for chaining. There
026 * are exceptions, usually where multiple GreasedRegion values are returned and the instance is not modified.
027 * <br>
028 * Typical usage involves constructing a GreasedRegion from some input data, like a char[][] for a map or a double[][]
029 * from DijkstraMap, and modifying it spatially with expand(), retract(), flood(), etc. It's common to mix in data from
030 * other GreasedRegions with and() (which gets the intersection of two GreasedRegions and stores it in one), or() (which
031 * is like and() but for the union), xor() (like and() but for exclusive or, finding only cells that are on in exactly
032 * one of the two GreasedRegions), and andNot() (which can be considered the "subtract another region from me" method).
033 * There are 8-way (Chebyshev distance) variants on all of the spatial methods, and methods without "8way" in the name
034 * are either 4-way (Manhattan distance) or not affected by distance measurement. Once you have a GreasedRegion, you may
035 * want to:
036 * <ul>
037 *     <li>get a single random point from it (use {@link #singleRandom(IRNG)}),</li>
038 *     <li>get several random points from it with random sampling (use {@link #randomPortion(IRNG, int)}),</li>
039 *     <li>mutate the current GreasedRegion to keep random points from it with random sampling (use {@link #randomRegion(IRNG, int)}),</li>
040 *     <li>get random points that are likely to be separated (use {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)} with
041 *     a random long for the last parameter, or {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double)} if you don't want a random seed),</li>
042 *     <li>do what any of the above "separated" methods can do, but mutate the current GreasedRegion (use
043 *     {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int, long)} or {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double, int)}),</li>
044 *     <li>get all points from it (use {@link #asCoords()} to get a Coord array, or produce a 2D array of the contents
045 *     with {@link #decode()} or {@link #toChars(char, char)}),</li>
046 *     <li>use it to modify other 2D data, such as with {@link #mask(char[][], char)},
047 *     {@link #inverseMask(char[][], char)}, {@link #writeDoubles(double[][], double)}, or
048 *     {@link #writeIntsInto(int[][], int)}, along with variations on those.</li>
049 * </ul>
050 * <br>
051 * You may also want to produce some 2D data from one or more GreasedRegions, as with {@link #sum(GreasedRegion...)} or
052 * {@link #toChars()}. The most effective techniques regarding GreasedRegion involve multiple methods, like getting a
053 * few random points from an existing GreasedRegion representing floor tiles in a dungeon with
054 * {@link #randomRegion(IRNG, int)}, then finding a random expansion of those initial points with
055 * {@link #spill(GreasedRegion, int, IRNG)}, giving the original GreasedRegion of floor tiles as the first argument.
056 * This could be used to position puddles of water or toxic waste in a dungeon level, while still keeping the starting
057 * points and finished points within the boundaries of valid (floor) cells. If you wanted to place something like mold
058 * that can be on floors or on cells immediately adjacent to floors (like walls), you could call {@link #expand()} on
059 * the floor tiles before calling spill, allowing the spill to spread onto non-floor cells that are next to floors.
060 * <br>
061 * For efficiency, you can place one GreasedRegion into another (typically a temporary value that is no longer needed
062 * and can be recycled) using {@link #remake(GreasedRegion)}, or give the information that would normally be used to
063 * construct a fresh GreasedRegion to an existing one of the same dimensions with {@link #refill(boolean[][])} or any
064 * of the overloads of refill(). These re-methods don't do as much work as a constructor does if the width and height
065 * of their argument are identical to their current width and height, and don't create more garbage for the GC.
066 * <br>
067 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 6/24/2016.
068 */
069@Beta
070public class GreasedRegion extends Zone.Skeleton implements Collection<Coord>, Serializable, MutableZone {
071    private static final long serialVersionUID = 0;
072    private static final SobolQRNG sobol = new SobolQRNG(2);
073
074    public long[] data;
075    public int height;
076    public int width;
077    private int ySections;
078    private long yEndMask;
079    private boolean tallied;
080    private int ct;
081    private int[] counts;
082
083    private void tally()
084    {
085        ct = 0;
086        for (int i = 0, tmp; i < counts.length; i++) {
087            tmp = Long.bitCount(data[i]);
088            counts[i] = tmp == 0 ? 0 : (ct += tmp);
089        }
090        tallied = true;
091    }
092
093    /**
094     * Constructs an empty 64x64 GreasedRegion.
095     * GreasedRegions are mutable, so you can add to this with insert() or insertSeveral(), among others.
096     */
097    public GreasedRegion()
098    {
099        width = 64;
100        height = 64;
101        ySections = 1;
102        yEndMask = -1L;
103        data = new long[64];
104        counts = new int[64];
105        ct = 0;
106        tallied = true;
107    }
108
109    /**
110     * Constructs a GreasedRegion with the given rectangular boolean array, with width of bits.length and height of
111     * bits[0].length, any value of true considered "on", and any value of false considered "off."
112     * @param bits a rectangular 2D boolean array where true is on and false is off
113     */
114    public GreasedRegion(final boolean[][] bits)
115    {
116        width = bits.length;
117        height = bits[0].length;
118        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
119        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
120        data = new long[width * ySections];
121        for (int x = 0, xs = 0; x < width; x++, xs += ySections) {
122            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
123                if(bits[x][y]) data[xs + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
124            }
125        }
126        counts = new int[width * ySections];
127        tallied = false;
128    }
129    /**
130     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular boolean array, reusing the current data storage (without
131     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
132     * this are always cleared, then any value of true in map is considered "on", and any value of false in map is
133     * considered "off."
134     * @param map a rectangular 2D boolean array where true is on and false is off
135     * @return this for chaining
136     */
137    public GreasedRegion refill(final boolean[][] map) {
138        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
139            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
140            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
141                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
142                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= (map[x][y] ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
143                }
144            }
145            tallied = false;
146            return this;
147        } else {
148            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
149            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
150            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
151            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
152            data = new long[width * ySections];
153            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
154                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
155                    if(map[x][y]) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
156                }
157            }
158            counts = new int[width * ySections];
159            tallied = false;
160            return this;
161        }
162    }
163
164    /**
165     * Constructs a GreasedRegion with the given rectangular char array, with width of map.length and height of
166     * map[0].length, any value that equals yes is considered "on", and any other value considered "off."
167     * @param map a rectangular 2D char array where yes is on and everything else is off
168     * @param yes which char to encode as "on"
169     */
170    public GreasedRegion(final char[][] map, final char yes)
171    {
172        width = map.length;
173        height = map[0].length;
174        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
175        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
176        data = new long[width * ySections];
177        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
178            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
179                if(map[x][y] == yes) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
180            }
181        }
182        counts = new int[width * ySections];
183        tallied = false;
184    }
185    /**
186     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular char array, reusing the current data storage (without
187     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
188     * this are always cleared, then any value that equals yes is considered "on", and any other value considered "off."
189     * @param map a rectangular 2D char array where yes is on and everything else is off
190     * @param yes which char to encode as "on"
191     * @return this for chaining
192     */
193    public GreasedRegion refill(final char[][] map, final char yes) {

199                }
200            }

203        } else {
204            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;

220    /**
221     * Weird constructor that takes a String array, _as it would be printed_, so each String is a row and indexing would
222     * be done with y, x instead of the normal x, y.
223     * @param map String array (as printed, not the normal storage) where each String is a row
224     * @param yes the char to consider "on" in the GreasedRegion
225     */
226    public GreasedRegion(final String[] map, final char yes)
227    {
228        height = map.length;
229        width = map[0].length();
230        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
231        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
232        data = new long[width * ySections];
233        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
234            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
235                if(map[y].charAt(x) == yes) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
236            }
237        }
238        counts = new int[width * ySections];
239        tallied = false;
240    }
241
242    /**
243     * Weird refill method that takes a String array, _as it would be printed_, so each String is a row and indexing
244     * would be done with y, x instead of the normal x, y.
245     * @param map String array (as printed, not the normal storage) where each String is a row
246     * @param yes the char to consider "on" in the GreasedRegion
247     * @return this for chaining
248     */
249    public GreasedRegion refill(final String[] map, final char yes) {
250        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && height == map.length && width == map[0].length()) {
251            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
252            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
253                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
254                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= ((map[y].charAt(x) == yes) ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
255                }
256            }
257            tallied = false;
258            return this;
259        } else {
260            height = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
261            width = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length();
262            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
263            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
264            data = new long[width * ySections];
265            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
266                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
267                    if(map[y].charAt(y) == yes) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
268                }
269            }
270            counts = new int[width * ySections];
271            tallied = false;
272            return this;
273        }
274    }

280     */

331    /**
332     * Constructs this GreasedRegion using an int[][], treating cells as on if they are greater than or equal to lower
333     * and less than upper, or off otherwise.
334     * @param map an int[][] that should have some ints between lower and upper
335     * @param lower lower bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are at least equal to lower
336     * @param upper upper bound, exclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than upper
337     */
338    public GreasedRegion(final int[][] map, final int lower, final int upper)
339    {
340        width = map.length;
341        height = map[0].length;
342        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
343        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
344        data = new long[width * ySections];
345        int[] column;
346        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
347            column = map[x];
348            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
349                if(column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
350            }
351        }
352        counts = new int[width * ySections];
353        tallied = false;
354    }
355
356    /**
357     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular int array, reusing the current data storage (without
358     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
359     * this are always cleared, then cells are treated as on if they are greater than or equal to lower and less than
360     * upper, or off otherwise.
361     * @param map a rectangular 2D int array that should have some values between lower and upper
362     * @param lower lower bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are at least equal to lower
363     * @param upper upper bound, exclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than upper
364     * @return this for chaining
365     */
366    public GreasedRegion refill(final int[][] map, final int lower, final int upper) {
367        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
368            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
369            int[] column;
370            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
371                column = map[x];
372                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
373                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= ((column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
374                }
375            }
376            tallied = false;
377            return this;
378        } else {
379            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
380            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
381            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
382            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
383            data = new long[width * ySections];
384            int[] column;
385            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
386                column = map[x];
387                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
388                    if(column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
389                }
390            }
391            counts = new int[width * ySections];
392            tallied = false;
393            return this;
394        }
395    }

508            }
509            tallied = false;
510            return this;
511        } else {
512            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
513            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
514            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
515            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
516            data = new long[width * ySections];
517            short[] column;
518            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
519                column = map[x];
520                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
521                    if(column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
522                }
523            }
524            counts = new int[width * ySections];
525            tallied = false;
526            return this;
527        }
528    }
529    /**
530     * Constructs this GreasedRegion using a double[][] (typically one generated by
531     * {@link squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap}) that only stores two relevant states:  an "on" state for values less than
532     * or equal to upperBound (inclusive), and an "off" state for anything else.
533     * @param map a double[][] that probably relates in some way to DijkstraMap.
534     * @param upperBound upper inclusive; any double greater than this will be off, any others will be on
535     */
536    public GreasedRegion(final double[][] map, final double upperBound)
537    {
538        width = map.length;
539        height = map[0].length;
540        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
541        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
542        data = new long[width * ySections];
543        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
544            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
545                if(map[x][y] <= upperBound)
546                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
547            }
548        }
549        counts = new int[width * ySections];
550        tallied = false;
551    }
552    /**
553     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular double array, reusing the current data storage (without
554     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
555     * this are always cleared, then cells are treated as on if they are less than or equal to upperBound, or off
556     * otherwise.
557     * @param map a rectangular 2D double array that should usually have some values less than or equal to upperBound
558     * @param upperBound upper bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than or equal to this
559     * @return this for chaining
560     */
561    public GreasedRegion refill(final double[][] map, final double upperBound) {
562        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
563            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
564            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
565                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
566                    if(map[x][y] <= upperBound) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
567                }
568            }
569            tallied = false;
570            return this;
571        } else {
572            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
573            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
574            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
575            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
576            data = new long[width * ySections];
577            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
578                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
579                    if(map[x][y] <= upperBound) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
580                }
581            }
582            counts = new int[width * ySections];
583            tallied = false;
584            return this;
585        }
586    }
587
588    /**
589     * Constructs this GreasedRegion using a double[][] (typically one generated by
590     * {@link squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap}) that only stores two relevant states:  an "on" state for values between
591     * lowerBound (inclusive) and upperBound (exclusive), and an "off" state for anything else.
592     * @param map a double[][] that probably relates in some way to DijkstraMap.
593     * @param lowerBound lower inclusive; any double lower than this will be off, any equal to or greater than this,
594     *                   but less than upper, will be on
595     * @param upperBound upper exclusive; any double greater than or equal to this this will be off, any doubles both
596     *                   less than this and equal to or greater than lower will be on
597     */
598    public GreasedRegion(final double[][] map, final double lowerBound, final double upperBound)
599    {
600        width = map.length;
601        height = map[0].length;
602        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
603        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
604        data = new long[width * ySections];
605        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
606            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
607                if(map[x][y] >= lowerBound && map[x][y] < upperBound)
608                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
609            }
610        }
611        counts = new int[width * ySections];
612        tallied = false;
613    }
614    /**
615     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular double array, reusing the current data storage (without
616     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
617     * this are always cleared, then cells are treated as on if they are greater than or equal to lower and less than
618     * upper, or off otherwise.
619     * @param map a rectangular 2D double array that should have some values between lower and upper
620     * @param lower lower bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are at least equal to lower
621     * @param upper upper bound, exclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than upper
622     * @return this for chaining
623     */
624    public GreasedRegion refill(final double[][] map, final double lower, final double upper) {
625        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
626            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
627            double[] column;
628            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
629                column = map[x];
630                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
631                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= ((column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
632                }
633            }
634            tallied = false;
635            return this;
636        } else {
637            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
638            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
639            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
640            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
641            data = new long[width * ySections];
642            double[] column;
643            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
644                column = map[x];
645                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
646                    if(column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
647                }
648            }
649            counts = new int[width * ySections];
650            tallied = false;
651            return this;
652        }
653    }
654
655    /**
656     * Constructs this GreasedRegion using a double[][] (this was made for use inside
657     * {@link squidpony.squidgrid.BevelFOV}) that only stores two relevant states:  an "on" state for values between
658     * lowerBound (inclusive) and upperBound (exclusive), and an "off" state for anything else. This variant scales the
659     * input so each "on" position in map produces a 2x2 on area if scale is 2, a 3x3 area if scale is 3, and so on.
660     * @param map a double[][] that may relate in some way to BevelFOV
661     * @param lowerBound lower inclusive; any double lower than this will be off, any equal to or greater than this,
662     *                   but less than upper, will be on
663     * @param upperBound upper exclusive; any double greater than or equal to this this will be off, any doubles both
664     *                   less than this and equal to or greater than lower will be on
665     * @param scale      the size of the square of cells in this that each "on" value in map will correspond to
666     */
667    public GreasedRegion(final double[][] map, final double lowerBound, final double upperBound, int scale)
668    {
669        scale = Math.min(63, Math.max(1, scale));
670        int baseWidth = map.length, baseHeight = map[0].length;
671        width =  baseWidth * scale;
672        height = baseHeight * scale;
673        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
674        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
675        data = new long[width * ySections];
676        long shape = (1L << scale) - 1L, leftover;
677        for (int bx = 0, x = 0; bx < baseWidth; bx++, x += scale) {
678            for (int by = 0, y = 0; by < baseHeight; by++, y += scale) {
679                if(map[bx][by] >= lowerBound && map[bx][by] < upperBound) {
680                    for (int i = 0; i < scale; i++) {
681                        data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= shape << (y & 63);
682                        if((leftover = (y + scale - 1 & 63) + 1) < (y & 63) + 1 && (y + leftover >> 6) < ySections)
683                        {
684                            data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6) + 1] |= (1L << leftover) - 1L;
685                        }
686                    }
687                }
688            }
689        }
690        counts = new int[width * ySections];
691        tallied = false;
692    }
693    /**
694     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular double array, reusing the current data storage (without
695     * extra allocations) if {@code this.width == map.length * scale && this.height == map[0].length * scale}. The
696     * current values stored in this are always cleared, then cells are treated as on if they are greater than or equal
697     * to lower and less than upper, or off otherwise, before considering scaling. This variant scales the input so each
698     * "on" position in map produces a 2x2 on area if scale is 2, a 3x3 area if scale is 3, and so on.
699     * @param map a double[][] that may relate in some way to BevelFOV
700     * @param lowerBound lower inclusive; any double lower than this will be off, any equal to or greater than this,
701     *                   but less than upper, will be on
702     * @param upperBound upper exclusive; any double greater than or equal to this this will be off, any doubles both
703     *                   less than this and equal to or greater than lower will be on
704     * @param scale      the size of the square of cells in this that each "on" value in map will correspond to
705     * @return this for chaining
706     */
707    public GreasedRegion refill(final double[][] map, final double lowerBound, final double upperBound, int scale) {
708        scale = Math.min(63, Math.max(1, scale));
709        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length * scale && height == map[0].length * scale) {
710            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
711            double[] column;
712            int baseWidth = map.length, baseHeight = map[0].length;
713            long shape = (1L << scale) - 1L, leftover;
714            for (int bx = 0, x = 0; bx < baseWidth; bx++, x += scale) {
715                column = map[bx];
716                for (int by = 0, y = 0; by < baseHeight; by++, y += scale) {
717                    if(column[by] >= lowerBound && column[by] < upperBound) {
718                        for (int i = 0; i < scale; i++) {
719                            data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= shape << (y & 63);
720                            if((leftover = (y + scale - 1 & 63) + 1) < (y & 63) + 1 && (y + leftover >> 6) < ySections)
721                            {
722                                data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6) + 1] |= (1L << leftover) - 1L;
723                            }
724                        }
725                    }
726                }
727            }
728            tallied = false;
729            return this;
730        } else {
731            int baseWidth = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length,
732                    baseHeight = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
733            width =  baseWidth * scale;
734            height = baseHeight * scale;
735            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
736            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
737            data = new long[width * ySections];
738            long shape = (1L << scale) - 1L, leftover;
739            for (int bx = 0, x = 0; bx < baseWidth; bx++, x += scale) {
740                for (int by = 0, y = 0; by < baseHeight; by++, y += scale) {
741                    if(map[bx][by] >= lowerBound && map[bx][by] < upperBound) {
742                        for (int i = 0; i < scale; i++) {
743                            data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= shape << (y & 63);
744                            if((leftover = (y + scale - 1 & 63)) < y && y < height - leftover)
745                            {
746                                data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6) + 1] |= (1L << leftover) - 1L;
747                            }
748                        }
749                    }
750                }
751            }
752            counts = new int[width * ySections];
753            tallied = false;
754            return this;
755        }
756    }
757
758    /**
759     * Constructs a GreasedRegion with the given 1D boolean array, with the given width and height, where an [x][y]
760     * position is obtained from bits given an index n with x = n / height, y = n % height, any value of true
761     * considered "on", and any value of false considered "off."
762     * @param bits a 1D boolean array where true is on and false is off
763     * @param width the width of the desired GreasedRegion; width * height should equal bits.length
764     * @param height the height of the desired GreasedRegion; width * height should equal bits.length
765     */
766    public GreasedRegion(final boolean[] bits, final int width, final int height)
767    {
768        this.width = width;
769        this.height = height;
770        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
771        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
772        data = new long[width * ySections];
773        for (int a = 0, x = 0, y = 0; a < bits.length; a++, x = a / height, y = a % height) {
774            if(bits[a]) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
775        }
776        counts = new int[width * ySections];
777        tallied = false;
778    }
779    /**
780     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given 1D boolean array, reusing the current data storage (without
781     * extra allocations) if this.width == width and this.height == height, where an [x][y]
782     * position is obtained from bits given an index n with x = n / height, y = n % height, any value of true
783     * considered "on", and any value of false considered "off."
784     * @param bits a 1D boolean array where true is on and false is off
785     * @param width the width of the desired GreasedRegion; width * height should equal bits.length
786     * @param height the height of the desired GreasedRegion; width * height should equal bits.length
787     * @return this for chaining
788     */
789    public GreasedRegion refill(final boolean[] bits, final int width, final int height) {
790        if (bits != null && this.width == width && this.height == height) {
791            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
792            for (int a = 0, x = 0, y = 0; a < bits.length; a++, x = a / height, y = a % height) {
793                data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= (bits[a] ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
794            }
795            tallied = false;
796            return this;
797        } else {
798            this.width = (bits == null || width < 0) ? 0 : width;
799            this.height = (bits == null || bits.length <= 0 || height < 0) ? 0 : height;
800            ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
801            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
802            data = new long[this.width * ySections];
803            if(bits != null) {
804                for (int a = 0, x = 0, y = 0; a < bits.length; a++, x = a / this.height, y = a % this.height) {
805                    if (bits[a]) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
806                }
807            }
808            counts = new int[width * ySections];
809            tallied = false;
810            return this;
811        }
812    }
813
814    /**
815     * Constructor for an empty GreasedRegion of the given width and height.
816     * GreasedRegions are mutable, so you can add to this with insert() or insertSeveral(), among others.
817     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
818     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
819     */
820    public GreasedRegion(final int width, final int height)
821    {
822        this.width = width;
823        this.height = height;
824        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
825        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
826        data = new long[width * ySections];
827        counts = new int[width  * ySections];
828        ct = 0;
829        tallied = true;
830    }
831
832    /**
833     * If this GreasedRegion has the same width and height passed as parameters, this acts the same as {@link #empty()},
834     * makes no allocations, and returns this GreasedRegion with its contents all "off"; otherwise, this does allocate
835     * a differently-sized amount of internal data to match the new width and height, sets the fields to all match the
836     * new width and height, and returns this GreasedRegion with its new width and height, with all contents "off". This
837     * is meant for cases where a GreasedRegion may be reused effectively, but its size may not always be the same.
838     * @param width the width to potentially resize this GreasedRegion to
839     * @param height the height to potentially resize this GreasedRegion to
840     * @return this GreasedRegion, always with all contents "off", and with the height and width set.
841     */
842    public GreasedRegion resizeAndEmpty(final int width, final int height) {
843        if (width == this.width && height == this.height) {
844            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
845            Arrays.fill(counts, 0);
846            ct = 0;
847            tallied = true;
848        } else {
849            this.width = (width <= 0) ? 0 : width;
850            this.height = (height <= 0) ? 0 : height;
851            ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
852            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
853            data = new long[this.width * ySections];
854            counts = new int[this.width * ySections];
855            ct = 0;
856            tallied = true;
857        }
858        return this;
859
860    }
861
862    /**
863     * Constructor for a GreasedRegion that contains a single "on" cell, and has the given width and height.
864     * Note that to avoid confusion with the constructor that takes multiple Coord values, this takes the single "on"
865     * Coord first, while the multiple-Coord constructor takes its vararg or array of Coords last.
866     * @param single the one (x,y) point to store as "on" in this GreasedRegion
867     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
868     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
869     */
870    public GreasedRegion(final Coord single, final int width, final int height)
871    {
872        this.width = width;
873        this.height = height;
874        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
875        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
876        data = new long[width * ySections];
877        counts = new int[width * ySections];
878        if(single.x < width && single.y < height && single.x >= 0 && single.y >= 0)
879        {
880            data[ct = single.x * ySections + (single.y >> 6)] |= 1L << (single.y & 63);
881            counts[ct] = 1;
882            ct = 1;
883            tallied = true;
884        }
885        else
886        {
887            ct = 0;
888            tallied = true;
889        }
890    }
891
892    /**
893     * Constructor for a GreasedRegion that can have several "on" cells specified, and has the given width and height.
894     * Note that to avoid confusion with the constructor that takes one Coord value, this takes the vararg or array of
895     * Coords last, while the single-Coord constructor takes its one Coord first.
896     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
897     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
898     * @param points an array or vararg of Coord to store as "on" in this GreasedRegion
899     */
900    public GreasedRegion(final int width, final  int height, final Coord... points)
901    {
902        this.width = width;
903        this.height = height;
904        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
905        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
906        data = new long[width * ySections];
907        if(points != null)
908        {
909            for (int i = 0, x, y; i < points.length; i++) {
910                x = points[i].x;
911                y = points[i].y;
912                if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
913                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
914            }
915        }
916        counts = new int[width * ySections];
917        tallied = false;
918    }

920    /**
921     * Constructor for a GreasedRegion that can have several "on" cells specified, and has the given width and height.
922     * Note that to avoid confusion with the constructor that takes one Coord value, this takes the Iterable of
923     * Coords last, while the single-Coord constructor takes its one Coord first.
924     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
925     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
926     * @param points an array or vararg of Coord to store as "on" in this GreasedRegion
927     */
928    public GreasedRegion(final int width, final int height, final Iterable<Coord> points)
929    {
930        this.width = width;
931        this.height = height;
932        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
933        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
934        data = new long[width * ySections];
935        if(points != null) {
936            int x, y;
937            for (Coord c : points) {
938                x = c.x;
939                y = c.y;
940                if (x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
941                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
942            }
943        }
944        counts = new int[width * ySections];
945        tallied = false;
946
947    }

949    /**
950     * Constructor for a random GreasedRegion of the given width and height, typically assigning approximately half of
951     * the cells in this to "on" and the rest to off. A RandomnessSource can be slightly more efficient than an RNG when
952     * you're making a lot of calls on it.
953     * @param random a RandomnessSource that should have a good nextLong() method; DiverRNG is excellent but Lathe32RNG is faster on GWT (only there) 
954     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
955     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
956     */
957    public GreasedRegion(final RandomnessSource random, final int width, final int height)
958    {
959        this.width = width;
960        this.height = height;
961        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
962        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
963        data = new long[width * ySections];
964        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
965            data[i] = random.nextLong();
966        }
967        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
968            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
969                data[a] &= yEndMask;
970            }
971        }
972        counts = new int[width * ySections];
973        tallied = false;
974    }
975    /**
976     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion by filling it with random values from random, reusing the current data storage
977     * (without extra allocations) if this.width == width and this.height == height, and typically assigning
978     * approximately half of the cells in this to "on" and the rest to off. A RandomnessSource can be slightly more
979     * efficient than an RNG when you're making a lot of calls on it.
980     * @param random a RandomnessSource that should have a good nextLong() method; DiverRNG is excellent but Lathe32RNG is faster on GWT (only there) 
981     * @param width the width of the desired GreasedRegion
982     * @param height the height of the desired GreasedRegion
983     * @return this for chaining
984     */
985    public GreasedRegion refill(final RandomnessSource random, final int width, final int height) {
986        if (random != null){
987            if(this.width == width && this.height == height) {
988                for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
989                    data[i] = random.nextLong();
990                }
991            } else {
992                this.width = (width <= 0) ? 0 : width;
993                this.height = (height <= 0) ? 0 : height;
994                ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
995                yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
996                data = new long[this.width * ySections];
997                for (int i = 0; i < this.width * ySections; i++) {
998                    data[i] = random.nextLong();
999                }
1000                counts = new int[this.width * ySections];
1001            }
1002            if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1003                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1004                    data[a] &= yEndMask;
1005                }
1006            }
1007            tallied = false;
1008        }
1009        return this;
1010    }

1012    /**
1013     * Constructor for a random GreasedRegion of the given width and height, typically assigning approximately half of
1014     * the cells in this to "on" and the rest to off. A RandomnessSource can be slightly more efficient than an RNG when
1015     * you're making a lot of calls on it, so you may prefer {@link #GreasedRegion(RandomnessSource, int, int)}.
1016     * @param random an IRNG, such as an RNG, that this will use to generate its contents
1017     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
1018     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
1019     */
1020    public GreasedRegion(final IRNG random, final int width, final int height)
1021    {
1022        this.width = width;
1023        this.height = height;
1024        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1025        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1026        data = new long[width * ySections];
1027        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1028            data[i] = random.nextLong();
1029        }
1030        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1031            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1032                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1033            }
1034        }
1035        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1036        tallied = false;
1037    }
1038    /**
1039     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion by filling it with random values from random, reusing the current data storage
1040     * (without extra allocations) if this.width == width and this.height == height, and typically assigning
1041     * approximately half of the cells in this to "on" and the rest to off.
1042     * @param random an IRNG that should have a good nextLong() method; an RNG constructed with the default RandomnessSource will be fine
1043     * @param width the width of the desired GreasedRegion
1044     * @param height the height of the desired GreasedRegion
1045     * @return this for chaining
1046     */
1047    public GreasedRegion refill(final IRNG random, final int width, final int height) {
1048        if (random != null){
1049            if(this.width == width && this.height == height) {
1050                for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1051                    data[i] = random.nextLong();
1052                }
1053            } else {
1054                this.width = (width <= 0) ? 0 : width;
1055                this.height = (height <= 0) ? 0 : height;
1056                ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
1057                yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
1058                data = new long[this.width * ySections];
1059                for (int i = 0; i < this.width * ySections; i++) {
1060                    data[i] = random.nextLong();
1061                }
1062                counts = new int[width * ySections];
1063            }
1064            if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1065                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1066                    data[a] &= yEndMask;
1067                }
1068            }
1069            tallied = false;
1070        }
1071        return this;
1072    }
1073
1074    /**
1075     * Constructor for a random GreasedRegion of the given width and height, trying to set the given fraction of cells
1076     * to on. Depending on the value of fraction, this makes between 0 and 6 calls to the nextLong() method of random's
1077     * internal RandomnessSource, per 64 cells of this GreasedRegion (if height is not a multiple of 64, round up to get
1078     * the number of calls this makes). As such, this sacrifices the precision of the fraction to obtain significantly
1079     * better speed than generating one random number per cell, although the precision is probably good enough (fraction
1080     * is effectively rounded down to the nearest multiple of 0.015625, and clamped between 0.0 and 1.0). The parameter
1081     * {@code random} can be an object like a {@link DiverRNG}, an {@link RNG} backed by a well-distributed
1082     * RandomnessSource like its default, DiverRNG, a {@link GWTRNG} (especially if you target GWT, where it will
1083     * perform much better than most alternatives), or any of various other RandomnessSource implementations that
1084     * distribute bits well for {@link RandomnessSource#nextLong()}, but should not be intentionally-biased RNGs like
1085     * {@link DharmaRNG} or {@link EditRNG}, nor double-based QRNGs like {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} or {@link SobolQRNG}.
1086     * @param random a RandomnessSource that should produce high-quality long values, like the defaults for {@link RNG}
1087     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0 (clamped), only considering a precision of 1/64.0 (0.015625) between steps
1088     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
1089     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
1090     */
1091    public GreasedRegion(final RandomnessSource random, final double fraction, final int width, final int height)
1092    {
1093        this.width = width;
1094        this.height = height;
1095        int bitCount = (int) (fraction * 64);
1096        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1097        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1098        data = new long[width * ySections];
1099        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1100            data[i] = approximateBits(random, bitCount);
1101        }
1102        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1103            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1104                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1105            }
1106        }
1107        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1108        tallied = false;
1109    }
1110    /**
1111     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion randomly, reusing the current data storage (without extra allocations) if this.width
1112     * == width and this.height == height, while trying to set the given fraction of cells to on. Depending on the value
1113     * of fraction, this makes between 0 and 6 calls to the nextLong() method of random's internal RandomnessSource, per
1114     * 64 cells of this GreasedRegion (if height is not a multiple of 64, round up to get the number of calls this
1115     * makes). As such, this sacrifices the precision of the fraction to obtain significantly better speed than
1116     * generating one random number per cell, although the precision is probably good enough (fraction is effectively
1117     * rounded down to the nearest multiple of 0.015625, and clamped between 0.0 and 1.0). The parameter {@code random}
1118     * can be an object like a {@link DiverRNG}, an {@link RNG} backed by a well-distributed RandomnessSource like its
1119     * default, DiverRNG, a {@link GWTRNG} (especially if you target GWT, where it will perform much better than most
1120     * alternatives), or any of various other RandomnessSource implementations that distribute bits well for
1121     * {@link RandomnessSource#nextLong()}, but should not be intentionally-biased RNGs like {@link DharmaRNG} or
1122     * {@link EditRNG}, nor double-based QRNGs like {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} or {@link SobolQRNG}.
1123     * @param random a RandomnessSource that should produce high-quality long values, like the defaults for {@link RNG}
1124     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0 (clamped), only considering a precision of 1/64.0 (0.015625) between steps
1125     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
1126     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
1127     * @return this for chaining
1128     */
1129    public GreasedRegion refill(final RandomnessSource random, final double fraction, final int width, final int height) {
1130        if (random != null){
1131            int bitCount = (int) (fraction * 64);
1132            if(this.width == width && this.height == height) {
1133                for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1134                    data[i] = approximateBits(random, bitCount);
1135                }
1136            } else {
1137                this.width = (width <= 0) ? 0 : width;
1138                this.height = (height <= 0) ? 0 : height;
1139                ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
1140                yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
1141                data = new long[this.width * ySections];
1142                for (int i = 0; i < this.width * ySections; i++) {
1143                    data[i] = approximateBits(random, bitCount);
1144                }
1145                counts = new int[width * ySections];
1146            }
1147            if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1148                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1149                    data[a] &= yEndMask;
1150                }
1151            }
1152        }
1153        tallied = false;
1154        return this;
1155    }

1157    /**
1158     * Copy constructor that takes another GreasedRegion and copies all of its data into this new one.
1159     * If you find yourself frequently using this constructor and assigning it to the same variable, consider using the
1160     * {@link #remake(GreasedRegion)} method on the variable instead, which will, if it has the same width and height
1161     * as the other GreasedRegion, avoid creating garbage and quickly fill the variable with the other's contents.
1162     * @see #copy() for a convenience method that just uses this constructor
1163     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will be copied into this new GreasedRegion
1164     */
1165    public GreasedRegion(final GreasedRegion other)
1166    {
1167        width = other.width;
1168        height = other.height;
1169        ySections = other.ySections;
1170        yEndMask = other.yEndMask;
1171        data = new long[width * ySections];
1172        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1173        System.arraycopy(other.data, 0, data, 0, width * ySections);
1174        System.arraycopy(other.counts, 0, counts, 0, width * ySections);
1175        ct  = other.ct;
1176        tallied = other.tallied;
1177    }

1179    /**
1180     * Primarily for internal use, this constructor copies data2 exactly into the internal long array the new
1181     * GreasedRegion will use, and does not perform any validation steps to ensure that cells that would be "on" but are
1182     * outside the actual height of the GreasedRegion are actually removed (this only matters if height is not a
1183     * multiple of 64).
1184     * @param data2 a long array that is typically from another GreasedRegion, and would be hard to make otherwise
1185     * @param width the width of the GreasedRegion to construct
1186     * @param height the height of the GreasedRegion to construct
1187     */
1188    public GreasedRegion(final long[] data2, final int width, final int height)
1189    {
1190        this.width = width;
1191        this.height = height;
1192        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1193        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1194        data = new long[width * ySections];
1195        System.arraycopy(data2, 0, data, 0, width * ySections);
1196        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1197            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1198                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1199            }
1200        }
1201        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1202        tallied = false;
1203    }
1204
1205    /**
1206     * Primarily for internal use, this constructor copies data2 into the internal long array the new GreasedRegion will
1207     * use, but treats data2 as having the dimensions [dataWidth][dataHeight], and uses the potentially-different
1208     * dimensions [width][height] for the constructed GreasedRegion. This will truncate data2 on width, height, or both
1209     * if width or height is smaller than dataWidth or dataHeight. It will fill extra space with all "off" if width or
1210     * height is larger than dataWidth or dataHeight. It will interpret data2 as the same 2D shape regardless of the
1211     * width or height it is being assigned to, and data2 will not be reshaped by truncation.
1212     * @param data2 a long array that is typically from another GreasedRegion, and would be hard to make otherwise
1213     * @param dataWidth the width to interpret data2 as having
1214     * @param dataHeight the height to interpret data2 as having
1215     * @param width the width of the GreasedRegion to construct
1216     * @param height the height of the GreasedRegion to construct
1217     */
1218    public GreasedRegion(final long[] data2, final int dataWidth, final int dataHeight, final int width, final int height)
1219    {
1220        this.width = width;
1221        this.height = height;
1222        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1223        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1224        data = new long[width * ySections];
1225
1226        final int ySections2 = (dataHeight + 63) >> 6;
1227        if(ySections2 == 0)
1228        {
1229            counts = new int[0];
1230            tallied = false;
1231            return;
1232        }
1233        if(ySections == 1) {
1234            System.arraycopy(data2, 0, data, 0, Math.min(dataWidth, width));
1235        }
1236        else
1237        {
1238            if(dataHeight >= height) {
1239                for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < width && i < dataWidth; i += ySections2, j += ySections) {
1240                    System.arraycopy(data2, i, data, j, ySections);
1241                }
1242            }
1243            else
1244            {
1245                for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < width && i < dataWidth; i += ySections2, j += ySections) {
1246                    System.arraycopy(data2, i, data, j, ySections2);
1247                }
1248            }
1249        }
1250        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1251            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1252                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1253            }
1254        }
1255        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1256        tallied = false;
1257    }
1258    /**
1259     * Primarily for internal use, this method copies data2 into the internal long array the new GreasedRegion will
1260     * use, but treats data2 as having the dimensions [dataWidth][dataHeight], and uses the potentially-different
1261     * dimensions [width][height] for this GreasedRegion, potentially re-allocating the internal data this uses if width
1262     * and/or height are different from what they were. This will truncate data2 on width, height, or both if width or
1263     * height is smaller than dataWidth or dataHeight. It will fill extra space with all "off" if width or height is
1264     * larger than dataWidth or dataHeight. It will interpret data2 as the same 2D shape regardless of the width or
1265     * height it is being assigned to, and data2 will not be reshaped by truncation.
1266     * @param data2 a long array that is typically from another GreasedRegion, and would be hard to make otherwise
1267     * @param dataWidth the width to interpret data2 as having
1268     * @param dataHeight the height to interpret data2 as having
1269     * @param width the width to set this GreasedRegion to have
1270     * @param height the height to set this GreasedRegion to have
1271     */
1272    public GreasedRegion refill(final long[] data2, final int dataWidth, final int dataHeight, final int width, final int height)
1273    {
1274        if(width != this.width || height != this.height) {
1275            this.width = width;
1276            this.height = height;
1277            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1278            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1279            data = new long[width * ySections];
1280            counts = new int[width * ySections];
1281        }
1282        else {
1283            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
1284        }
1285        final int ySections2 = (dataHeight + 63) >> 6;
1286        if(ySections2 == 0)
1287            return this;
1288        if(ySections == 1) {
1289            System.arraycopy(data2, 0, data, 0, Math.min(dataWidth, width));
1290        }
1291        else
1292        {
1293            if(dataHeight >= height) {
1294                for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < width && i < dataWidth; i += ySections2, j += ySections) {
1295                    System.arraycopy(data2, i, data, j, ySections);
1296                }
1297            }
1298            else
1299            {
1300                for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < width && i < dataWidth; i += ySections2, j += ySections) {
1301                    System.arraycopy(data2, i, data, j, ySections2);
1302                }
1303            }
1304        }
1305        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1306            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1307                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1308            }
1309        }
1310        tallied = false;
1311        return this;
1312    }
1313
1314    /**
1315     * A useful method for efficiency, remake() reassigns this GreasedRegion to have its contents replaced by other. If
1316     * other and this GreasedRegion have identical width and height, this is very efficient and performs no additional
1317     * allocations, simply replacing the cell data in this with the cell data from other. If width and height are not
1318     * both equal between this and other, this does allocate a new data array, but still reassigns this GreasedRegion
1319     * in-place and acts similarly to when width and height are both equal (it just uses some more memory).
1320     * <br>
1321     * Using remake() or the similar refill() methods in chains of operations on multiple GreasedRegions can be key to
1322     * maintaining good performance and memory usage. You often can recycle a no-longer-used GreasedRegion by assigning
1323     * a GreasedRegion you want to keep to it with remake(), then mutating either the remade value or the one that was
1324     * just filled into this but keeping one version around for later usage.
1325     * @param other another GreasedRegion to replace the data in this GreasedRegion with
1326     * @return this for chaining
1327     */
1328    public GreasedRegion remake(GreasedRegion other) {
1329        if (width == other.width && height == other.height) {
1330            System.arraycopy(other.data, 0, data, 0, width * ySections);
1331            System.arraycopy(other.counts, 0, counts, 0, width * ySections);
1332            ct = other.ct;
1333            tallied = other.tallied;
1334            return this;
1335        } else {
1336            width = other.width;
1337            height = other.height;
1338            ySections = other.ySections;
1339            yEndMask = other.yEndMask;
1340            data = new long[width * ySections];
1341            System.arraycopy(other.data, 0, data, 0, width * ySections);
1342            System.arraycopy(other.counts, 0, counts, 0, width * ySections);
1343            ct = other.ct;
1344            tallied = other.tallied;
1345            return this;
1346        }
1347    }
1348
1349    /**
1350     * Changes the width and/or height of this GreasedRegion, enlarging or shrinking starting at the edges where
1351     * {@code x == width - 1} and {@code y == height - 1}. There isn't an especially efficient way to expand from the
1352     * other edges, but this method is able to copy data in bulk, so at least this method should be very fast. You can
1353     * use {@code insert(int, int, GreasedRegion)} if you want to place one GreasedRegion inside another one,
1354     * potentially with a different size. The space created by any enlargement starts all off; shrinking doesn't change
1355     * the existing data where it isn't removed by the shrink.
1356     * @param widthChange the amount to change width by; can be positive, negative, or zero
1357     * @param heightChange the amount to change height by; can be positive, negative, or zero
1358     * @return this for chaining
1359     */
1360    public GreasedRegion alterBounds(int widthChange, int heightChange)
1361    {
1362        int newWidth = width + widthChange;
1363        int newHeight = height + heightChange;
1364        if(newWidth <= 0 || newHeight <= 0)
1365        {
1366            width = 0;
1367            height = 0;
1368            ySections= 0;
1369            yEndMask = -1;
1370            data = new long[0];
1371            counts = new int[0];
1372            ct = 0;
1373            tallied = true;
1374            return this;
1375        }
1376        int newYSections = (newHeight + 63) >> 6;
1377        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (newHeight & 63));
1378        long[] newData = new long[newWidth * newYSections];         
1379        counts = new int[newWidth * newYSections];
1380        
1381        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < newWidth; x++) {
1382            for (int ys = 0; ys < ySections && ys < newYSections; ys++) {
1383                newData[x * newYSections + ys] = data[x * ySections + ys];
1384            }
1385        }
1386        ySections = newYSections;
1387        width = newWidth;
1388        height = newHeight;
1389        data = newData;
1390        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1391            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1392                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1393            }
1394        }
1395        tallied = false;
1396        return this;
1397    }
1398
1399    /**
1400     * Sets the cell at x,y to on if value is true or off if value is false. Does nothing if x,y is out of bounds.
1401     * @param value the value to set in the cell
1402     * @param x the x-position of the cell
1403     * @param y the y-position of the cell
1404     * @return this for chaining
1405     */
1406    public GreasedRegion set(boolean value, int x, int y)
1407    {
1408        if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0) {
1409            if(value)
1410                data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
1411            else
1412                data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] &= ~(1L << (y & 63));
1413            tallied = false;
1414        }
1415        return this;
1416    }

1418    /**
1419     * Sets the cell at point to on if value is true or off if value is false. Does nothing if point is out of bounds,
1420     * or if point is null.
1421     * @param value the value to set in the cell
1422     * @param point the x,y Coord of the cell to set
1423     * @return this for chaining
1424     */
1425    public GreasedRegion set(boolean value, Coord point)
1426    {
1427        if(point == null) return this;
1428        return set(value, point.x, point.y);
1429    }

1431    /**
1432     * Sets the cell at x,y to "on". Does nothing if x,y is out of bounds.
1433     * More efficient, slightly, than {@link #set(boolean, int, int)} if you just need to set a cell to "on".
1434     * @param x the x-position of the cell
1435     * @param y the y-position of the cell
1436     * @return this for chaining
1437     */
1438    public GreasedRegion insert(int x, int y)
1439    {
1440        if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
1441        {
1442            data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
1443            tallied = false;
1444        }
1445        return this;
1446    }

1448    /**
1449     * Sets the given cell, "tightly" encoded for a specific width/height as by {@link #asTightEncoded()}, to "on".
1450     * Does nothing if the cell is out of bounds.
1451     * @param tight a cell tightly encoded for this GreasedRegion's width and height
1452     * @return this for chaining
1453     */
1454    public GreasedRegion insert(int tight)
1455    {
1456        if(tight < width * height && tight >= 0)
1457        {
1458            data[(tight % width) * ySections + ((tight / width) >>> 6)] |= 1L << ((tight / width) & 63);
1459            tallied = false;
1460        }
1461        return this;
1462    }
1463    /**
1464     * Sets the cell at point to "on". Does nothing if point is out of bounds, or if point is null.
1465     * More efficient, slightly, than {@link #set(boolean, Coord)} if you just need to set a cell to "on".
1466     * @param point the x,y Coord of the cell
1467     * @return this for chaining
1468     */
1469    public GreasedRegion insert(Coord point)
1470    {
1471
1472        if(point == null) return this;
1473        return insert(point.x, point.y);
1474    }
1475
1476    /**
1477     * Takes another GreasedRegion, called other, with potentially different size and inserts its "on" cells into thi
1478     * GreasedRegion at the given x,y offset, allowing negative x and/or y to put only part of other in this.
1479     * <br>
1480     * This is a rather complex method internally, but should be about as efficient as a general insert-region method
1481     * can be.
1482     * @param x the x offset to start inserting other at; may be negative
1483     * @param y the y offset to start inserting other at; may be negative
1484     * @param other the other GreasedRegion to insert
1485     * @return this for chaining
1486     */
1487    public GreasedRegion insert(int x, int y, GreasedRegion other)
1488    {
1489        if(other == null || other.ySections <= 0 || other.width <= 0)
1490            return this;
1491
1492        int start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, Math.min(other.width, other.width + x) - start),
1493        oys = other.ySections, jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
1494        originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump);
1495        long[] data2 = new long[other.width * ySections];
1496
1497        long prev, tmp;
1498        if(oys == ySections) {
1499            if (x < 0) {
1500                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1501                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1502                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1503                    }
1504                }
1505            } else if (x > 0) {
1506                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1507                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1508                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * ySections + oi];
1509                    }
1510                }
1511            } else {
1512                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1513                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1514                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * ySections + oi];
1515                    }
1516                }
1517            }
1518        }
1519        else if(oys < ySections)
1520        {
1521            if (x < 0) {
1522                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1523                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1524                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1525                    }
1526                }
1527            } else if (x > 0) {
1528                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {// oi < oys - Math.max(0, jump)
1529                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1530                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1531                    }
1532                }
1533            } else {
1534                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1535                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1536                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1537                    }
1538                }
1539            }
1540        }
1541        else
1542        {
1543            if (x < 0) {
1544                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1545                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1546                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1547                    }
1548                }
1549            } else if (x > 0) {
1550                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1551                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1552                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1553                    }
1554                }
1555            } else {
1556                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1557                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1558                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1559                    }
1560                }
1561            }
1562        }
1563
1564        if(lily < 0) {
1565            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1566                prev = 0L;
1567                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1568                    tmp = prev;
1569                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
1570                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
1571                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
1572                }
1573            }
1574        }
1575        else if(lily > 0) {
1576            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
1577                prev = 0L;
1578                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1579                    tmp = prev;
1580                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
1581                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
1582                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
1583                }
1584            }
1585        }
1586        len = Math.min(width, start + len);
1587        for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1588            for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1589                data[i * ySections + j] |= data2[i * ySections + j];
1590            }
1591        }
1592
1593        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1594            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1595                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1596            }
1597        }
1598        tallied = false;
1599        return this;
1600    }

1606            y = points[i].y;
1607            if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
1608            {
1609                data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
1610                tallied = false;
1611            }
1612        }
1613        return this;
1614    }

1616    public GreasedRegion insertSeveral(final int[] points)
1617    {
1618        for (int i = 0, tight; i < points.length; i++) {
1619            tight = points[i];
1620            if(tight < width * height && tight >= 0)
1621            {
1622                data[(tight % width) * ySections + ((tight / width) >>> 6)] |= 1L << ((tight / width) & 63);
1623                tallied = false;
1624            }
1625        }
1626        return this;
1627    }

1633            x = pt.x;
1634            y = pt.y;
1635            if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
1636            {

1638                tallied = false;
1639            }
1640        }
