1644    public GreasedRegion insertRectangle(int startX, int startY, int rectangleWidth, int rectangleHeight)
1645    {
1646        if(rectangleWidth < 1 || rectangleHeight < 1 || ySections <= 0)
1647            return this;
1648        if(startX < 0)
1649            startX = 0;
1650        else if(startX >= width)
1651            startX = width - 1;
1652        if(startY < 0)
1653            startY = 0;
1654        else if(startY >= height)
1655            startY = height - 1;
1656        int endX = Math.min(width, startX + rectangleWidth) - 1,
1657                endY = Math.min(height, startY + rectangleHeight) - 1,
1658                startSection = startY >> 6, endSection = endY >> 6;
1659        if(startSection < endSection)
1660        {
1661            long startMask = -1L << (startY & 63),
1662                    endMask = -1L >>> (~endY & 63);
1663            for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection; a <= endX * ySections + startSection; a += ySections) {
1664                data[a] |= startMask;
1665            }
1666            if(endSection - startSection > 1)
1667            {
1668                for (int b = 1; b < endSection - startSection; b++) {
1669                    for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection + b; a < endX * ySections + ySections; a += ySections) {
1670                        data[a] = -1;
1671                    }
1672                }
1673            }
1674            for (int a = startX * ySections + endSection; a <= endX * ySections + endSection; a += ySections) {
1675                data[a] |= endMask;
1676            }
1677        }
1678        else
1679        {
1680            long mask = (-1L << (startY & 63)) & (-1L >>> (~endY & 63));
1681            for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection; a <= endX * ySections + startSection; a += ySections) {
1682                data[a] |= mask;
1683            }
1684        }
1685
1686        if(yEndMask != -1L) {
1687            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1688                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1689            }
1690        }
1691        tallied = false;
1692        return this;
1693    }
1694
1695    public GreasedRegion insertCircle(Coord center, int radius)
1696    {
1697        float high, changedX;
1698        int rndX, rndY;
1699        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx) {
1700            changedX = dx - 0.25f * Math.signum(dx);
1701            rndX = Math.round(changedX);
1702            high = (float) Math.sqrt(radius * radius - changedX * changedX);             
1703            insert(center.x + rndX, center.y);
1704            for (float dy = high; dy >= 0.75f; --dy) {
1705                rndY = Math.round(dy - 0.25f);                 
1706                insert(center.x + rndX, center.y + rndY);
1707                insert(center.x + rndX, center.y - rndY);
1708            }
1709        }
1710        return this;
1711    }
1712
1713    public GreasedRegion remove(int x, int y)
1714    {
1715        if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
1716        {
1717            data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] &= ~(1L << (y & 63));
1718            tallied = false;
1719        }
1720        return this;
1721    }
1722    public GreasedRegion remove(Coord point)
1723    {
1724        return remove(point.x, point.y);
1725    }
1726    /**
1727     * Takes another GreasedRegion, called other, with potentially different size and removes its "on" cells from this
1728     * GreasedRegion at the given x,y offset, allowing negative x and/or y to remove only part of other in this.
1729     * <br>
1730     * This is a rather complex method internally, but should be about as efficient as a general remove-region method
1731     * can be. The code is identical to {@link #insert(int, int, GreasedRegion)} except that where insert only adds
1732     * cells, this only removes cells. Essentially, insert() is to {@link #or(GreasedRegion)} as remove() is to
1733     * {@link #andNot(GreasedRegion)}.
1734     * @param x the x offset to start removing other from; may be negative
1735     * @param y the y offset to start removing other from; may be negative
1736     * @param other the other GreasedRegion to remove
1737     * @return this for chaining
1738     */
1739    public GreasedRegion remove(int x, int y, GreasedRegion other)
1740    {
1741        if(other == null || other.ySections <= 0 || other.width <= 0)
1742            return this;
1743
1744        int start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, Math.min(other.width, other.width + x) - start),
1745                oys = other.ySections, jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y-1 >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
1746                originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump);
1747        long[] data2 = new long[other.width * ySections];
1748
1749        long prev, tmp;
1750        if(oys == ySections) {
1751            if (x < 0) {
1752                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1753                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1754                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1755                    }
1756                }
1757            } else if (x > 0) {
1758                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1759                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1760                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * ySections + oi];
1761                    }
1762                }
1763            } else {
1764                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1765                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1766                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * ySections + oi];
1767                    }
1768                }
1769            }
1770        }
1771        else if(oys < ySections)
1772        {
1773            if (x < 0) {
1774                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1775                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1776                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1777                    }
1778                }
1779            } else if (x > 0) {
1780                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {// oi < oys - Math.max(0, jump)
1781                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1782                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1783                    }
1784                }
1785            } else {
1786                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1787                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1788                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1789                    }
1790                }
1791            }
1792        }
1793        else
1794        {
1795            if (x < 0) {
1796                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1797                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1798                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1799                    }
1800                }
1801            } else if (x > 0) {
1802                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1803                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1804                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1805                    }
1806                }
1807            } else {
1808                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1809                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1810                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1811                    }
1812                }
1813            }
1814        }
1815
1816        if(lily < 0) {
1817            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1818                prev = 0L;
1819                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1820                    tmp = prev;
1821                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
1822                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
1823                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
1824                }
1825            }
1826        }
1827        else if(lily > 0) {
1828            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
1829                prev = 0L;
1830                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1831                    tmp = prev;
1832                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
1833                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
1834                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
1835                }
1836            }
1837        }
1838        len = Math.min(width, start + len);
1839        for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1840            for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1841                data[i * ySections + j] &= ~data2[i * ySections + j];
1842            }
1843        }
1844
1845        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1846            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1847                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1848            }
1849        }
1850        tallied = false;
1851
1852        return this;
1853    }

1883    public GreasedRegion removeRectangle(int startX, int startY, int rectangleWidth, int rectangleHeight)
1884    {
1885        if(startX < 0)
1886        {
1887            rectangleWidth += startX;
1888            startX = 0;
1889        }
1890        else if(startX >= width)
1891        {
1892            rectangleWidth = 1;
1893            startX = width - 1;
1894        }
1895        if(startY < 0)
1896        {
1897            rectangleHeight += startY;
1898            startY = 0;
1899        }
1900        else if(startY >= height)
1901        {
1902            rectangleHeight = 1;
1903            startY = height - 1;
1904        }
1905        if(rectangleWidth < 1 || rectangleHeight < 1 || ySections <= 0)
1906            return this;
1907        int endX = Math.min(width, startX + rectangleWidth) - 1,
1908                endY = Math.min(height, startY + rectangleHeight) - 1,
1909                startSection = startY >> 6, endSection = endY >> 6;
1910        if(startSection < endSection)
1911        {
1912            long startMask = ~(-1L << (startY & 63)),
1913                    endMask = ~(-1L >>> (~endY & 63));
1914            for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection; a <= endX * ySections + startSection; a += ySections) {
1915                data[a] &= startMask;
1916            }
1917            if(endSection - startSection > 1)
1918            {
1919                for (int b = 1; b < endSection - startSection; b++) {
1920                    for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection + b; a < endX * ySections + ySections; a += ySections) {
1921                        data[a] = 0;
1922                    }
1923                }
1924            }
1925            for (int a = startX * ySections + endSection; a <= endX * ySections + endSection; a += ySections) {
1926                data[a] &= endMask;
1927            }
1928        }
1929        else
1930        {
1931            long mask = ~((-1L << (startY & 63)) & (-1L >>> (~endY & 63)));
1932            for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection; a <= endX * ySections + startSection; a += ySections) {
1933                data[a] &= mask;
1934            }
1935        }
1936        tallied = false;
1937        return this;
1938    }
1939
1940    public GreasedRegion removeCircle(Coord center, int radius)
1941    {
1942        float high, changedX;
1943        int rndX, rndY;
1944        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx) {
1945            changedX = dx - 0.25f * Math.signum(dx);
1946            rndX = Math.round(changedX);
1947            high = (float) Math.sqrt(radius * radius - changedX * changedX);
1948            remove(center.x + rndX, center.y);
1949            for (float dy = high; dy >= 0.75f; --dy) {
1950                rndY = Math.round(dy - 0.25f);
1951                remove(center.x + rndX, center.y + rndY);
1952                remove(center.x + rndX, center.y - rndY);
1953            }
1954        }
1955        return this;
1956    }

1958    /**
1959     * Equivalent to {@link #clear()}, setting all cells to "off," but also returns this for chaining.
1960     * @return this for chaining
1961     */
1962    public GreasedRegion empty()
1963    {
1964        Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
1965        Arrays.fill(counts, 0);
1966        ct = 0;
1967        tallied = true;
1968        return this;
1969    }
1970
1971    /**
1972     * Sets all cells in this to "on."
1973     * @return this for chaining
1974     */
1975    public GreasedRegion allOn()
1976    {
1977        if(ySections > 0)
1978        {
1979            if(yEndMask == -1) {
1980                Arrays.fill(data, -1);
1981                Arrays.fill(counts, 64);
1982                ct = ySections * width << 6;
1983                tallied = true;
1984            }
1985            else
1986            {
1987                ct = Long.bitCount(yEndMask);
1988                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1989                    data[a] = yEndMask;
1990                    counts[a] = ct;
1991                    for (int i = 0; i < ySections - 1; i++) {
1992                        data[a-i-1] = -1;
1993                        counts[a-i-1] = 64;
1994                    }
1995                }
1996                ct *= width;
1997                ct += (ySections - 1) * width << 6;
1998                tallied = true;
1999            }
2000        }
2001        return this;
2002    }
2003
2004    /**
2005     * Sets all cells in this to "on" if contents is true, or "off" if contents is false.
2006     * @param contents true to set all cells to on, false to set all cells to off
2007     * @return this for chaining
2008     */
2009    public GreasedRegion fill(boolean contents)
2010    {
2011        if(contents)
2012        {
2013            if(ySections > 0)
2014            {
2015                if(yEndMask == -1) {
2016                    Arrays.fill(data, -1);
2017                    Arrays.fill(counts, 64);
2018                    ct = ySections * width << 6;
2019                    tallied = true;
2020                }
2021                else
2022                {
2023                    ct = Long.bitCount(yEndMask);
2024                    for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2025                        data[a] = yEndMask;
2026                        counts[a] = ct;
2027                        for (int i = 0; i < ySections - 1; i++) {
2028                            data[a-i-1] = -1;
2029                            counts[a-i-1] = 64;
2030                        }
2031                    }
2032                    ct *= width;
2033                    ct += (ySections - 1) * width << 6;
2034                    tallied = true;
2035                }
2036            }
2037            //else... what, if ySections is 0 there's nothing to do
2038        }
2039        else
2040        {
2041            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
2042            Arrays.fill(counts, 0);
2043            ct = 0;
2044            tallied = true;
2045        }
2046        return this;
2047    }
2048    /**
2049     * Turns all cells that are adjacent to the boundaries of the GreasedRegion to "off".
2050     * @return this for chaining
2051     */
2052    public GreasedRegion removeEdges()
2053    {
2054        if(ySections > 0) {
2055            for (int i = 0; i < ySections; i++) {
2056                data[i] = 0L;
2057                data[width * ySections - 1 - i] = 0L;
2058            }
2059            if (ySections == 1) {
2060                for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
2061                    data[i] &= yEndMask >>> 1 & -2L;
2062                }
2063            } else {
2064                for (int i = ySections; i < data.length - ySections; i += ySections) {
2065                    data[i] &= -2L;
2066                }
2067                for (int a = ySections * 2 - 1; a < data.length - ySections; a += ySections) {
2068                    data[a] &= yEndMask >>> 1;
2069                }
2070            }
2071            tallied = false;
2072        }
2073        return this;
2074    }
2075
2076    /**
2077     * Simple method that returns a newly-allocated copy of this GreasedRegion; modifications to one won't change the
2078     * other, and this method returns the copy while leaving the original unchanged.
2079     * @return a copy of this GreasedRegion; the copy can be changed without altering the original
2080     */
2081    public GreasedRegion copy()
2082    {
2083        return new GreasedRegion(this);
2084    }

2095            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
2096                bools[x][y] = (data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0;
2097            }

2166    /**
2167     * Returns this GreasedRegion's data as a StringBuilder, with each row made of the parameter on for "on" cells and
2168     * the parameter off for "off" cells, separated by newlines, with no trailing newline at the end.
2169     * @param on the char to use for "on" cells
2170     * @param off the char to use for "off" cells
2171     * @return a StringBuilder that stores each row of this GreasedRegion as chars, with rows separated by newlines.
2172     */
2173    public StringBuilder show(char on, char off)
2174    {
2175        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder((width+1) * height);
2176        for (int y = 0; y < height;) {
2177            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2178                sb.append((data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? on : off);
2179            }
2180            if(++y < height)
2181                sb.append('\n');
2182        }
2183        return sb;
2184    }

2202     * @param filler the char to use where this GreasedRegion stores an "off" cell

2205    public char[][] mask(char[][] map, char filler)

2208            return new char[0][0];

2214            }

2300            }

2368    /**
2369     * Union of two GreasedRegions, assigning the result into this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in either
2370     * GreasedRegion will be made "on" in this GreasedRegion.
2371     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2372     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2373     */
2374    public GreasedRegion or(GreasedRegion other)
2375    {
2376        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2377            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2378                data[x * ySections + y] |= other.data[x * ySections + y];
2379            }
2380        }
2381
2382        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2383            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2384                data[a] &= yEndMask;
2385            }
2386        }
2387        tallied = false;
2388
2389        return this;
2390    }

2392    /**
2393     * Intersection of two GreasedRegions, assigning the result into this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in both
2394     * GreasedRegions will be kept "on" in this GreasedRegion, but all other cells will be made "off."
2395     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2396     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2397     */
2398    public GreasedRegion and(GreasedRegion other)
2399    {
2400        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2401            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2402                data[x * ySections + y] &= other.data[x * ySections + y];
2403            }
2404        }
2405        tallied = false;
2406        return this;
2407    }

2409    /**
2410     * Intersection of two GreasedRegions, assigning the result into this GreasedRegion, with the special requirement
2411     * that other must be a 64x64 area, and the special property that other will be considered tiled to cover all of the
2412     * area of this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in both GreasedRegions (treating other as tiling) will be kept
2413     * "on" in this GreasedRegion, but all other cells will be made "off."
2414     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified but must be 64x64 in size; will act as if it tiles
2415     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2416     */
2417    public GreasedRegion andWrapping64(GreasedRegion other)
2418    {
2419        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2420            for (int y = 0; y < ySections; y++) {
2421                data[x * ySections + y] &= other.data[x & 63];
2422            }
2423        }
2424        tallied = false;
2425        return this;
2426    }
2427    /**
2428     * Difference of two GreasedRegions, assigning the result into this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in this
2429     * GreasedRegion and "off" in other will be kept "on" in this GreasedRegion, but all other cells will be made "off."
2430     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2431     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2432     * @see #notAnd(GreasedRegion) notAnd is a very similar method that acts sort-of in reverse of this method
2433     */
2434    public GreasedRegion andNot(GreasedRegion other)
2435    {
2436        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2437            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2438                data[x * ySections + y] &= ~other.data[x * ySections + y];
2439            }
2440        }
2441        tallied = false;
2442        return this;
2443    }

2445    /**
2446     * Like andNot, but subtracts this GreasedRegion from other and stores the result in this GreasedRegion, without
2447     * mutating other.
2448     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2449     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2450     * @see #andNot(GreasedRegion) andNot is a very similar method that acts sort-of in reverse of this method
2451     */
2452    public GreasedRegion notAnd(GreasedRegion other)
2453    {
2454        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2455            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2456                data[x * ySections + y] = other.data[x * ySections + y] & ~data[x * ySections + y];
2457            }
2458        }
2459        tallied = false;
2460        return this;
2461    }

2463    /**
2464     * Symmetric difference (more commonly known as exclusive or, hence the name) of two GreasedRegions, assigning the
2465     * result into this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in this and "off" in other, or "off" in this and "on" in
2466     * other, will be made "on" in this; all other cells will be made "off." Useful to find cells that are "on" in
2467     * exactly one of two GreasedRegions (not "on" in both, or "off" in both).
2468     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2469     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2470     */
2471    public GreasedRegion xor(GreasedRegion other)
2472    {
2473        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2474            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2475                data[x * ySections + y] ^= other.data[x * ySections + y];
2476            }
2477        }
2478
2479        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2480            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2481                data[a] &= yEndMask;
2482            }
2483        }
2484        tallied = false;
2485        return this;
2486    }

2488    /**
2489     * Negates this GreasedRegion, turning "on" to "off" and "off" to "on."
2490     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2491     */
2492    public GreasedRegion not()
2493    {
2494        for (int a = 0; a < data.length; a++)
2495        {
2496            data[a] = ~data[a];
2497        }
2498
2499        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2500            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2501                data[a] &= yEndMask;
2502            }
2503        }
2504        tallied = false;
2505        return this;
2506    }
2507
2508    /**
2509     * Moves the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion to the given x and y offset, removing cells that move out of bounds.
2510     * @param x the x offset to translate by; can be negative
2511     * @param y the y offset to translate by; can be negative
2512     * @return this for chaining
2513     */
2514    public GreasedRegion translate(int x, int y)
2515    {
2516        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0 || (x == 0 && y == 0))
2517            return this;
2518        int start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, width + x) - start,
2519                jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
2520                originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump);
2521        long[] data2 = new long[width * ySections];
2522
2523        long prev, tmp;
2524        if (x < 0) {
2525            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2526                for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
2527                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2528                }
2529            }
2530        } else if (x > 0) {
2531            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2532                for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
2533                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2534                }
2535            }
2536        } else {
2537            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2538                for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
2539                    data2[j * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2540                }
2541            }
2542        }
2543
2544        if(lily < 0) {
2545            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
2546                prev = 0L;
2547                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
2548                    tmp = prev;
2549                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
2550                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
2551                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2552                }
2553            }
2554        }
2555        else if(lily > 0) {
2556            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
2557                prev = 0L;
2558                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
2559                    tmp = prev;
2560                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
2561                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
2562                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2563                }
2564            }
2565        }
2566
2567
2568        if(yEndMask != -1) {
2569            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data2.length; a += ySections) {
2570                data2[a] &= yEndMask;
2571            }
2572        }
2573
2574        data = data2;
2575        tallied = false;
2576        return this;
2577    }
2578
2579    /**
2580     * Adds to this GreasedRegion with a moved set of its own "on" cells, moved to the given x and y offset.
2581     * Ignores cells that would be added out of bounds. Keeps all cells that are currently "on" unchanged.
2582     * @param x the x offset to translate by; can be negative
2583     * @param y the y offset to translate by; can be negative
2584     * @return this for chaining
2585     */
2586    public GreasedRegion insertTranslation(int x, int y)
2587    {
2588        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0 || (x == 0 && y == 0))
2589            return this;
2590        int start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, width + x) - start,
2591                jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
2592                originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump);
2593        long[] data2 = new long[width * ySections];
2594        long prev, tmp;
2595        if (x < 0) {
2596            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2597                for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
2598                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2599                }
2600            }
2601        } else if (x > 0) {
2602            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2603                for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
2604                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2605                }
2606            }
2607        } else {
2608            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2609                for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
2610                    data2[j * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2611                }
2612            }
2613        }
2614
2615        if(lily < 0) {
2616            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
2617                prev = 0L;
2618                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
2619                    tmp = prev;
2620                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
2621                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
2622                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2623                }
2624            }
2625        }
2626        else if(lily > 0) {
2627            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
2628                prev = 0L;
2629                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
2630                    tmp = prev;
2631                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
2632                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
2633                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2634                }
2635            }
2636        }
2637
2638        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
2639            data2[i] |= data[i];
2640        }
2641
2642
2643        if(yEndMask != -1) {
2644            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data2.length; a += ySections) {
2645                data2[a] &= yEndMask;
2646            }
2647        }
2648
2649        data = data2;
2650        tallied = false;
2651        return this;
2652    }

2654    /**
2655     * Effectively doubles the x and y values of each cell this contains (not scaling each cell to be larger, so each
2656     * "on" cell will be surrounded by "off" cells), and re-maps the positions so the given x and y in the doubled space
2657     * become 0,0 in the resulting GreasedRegion (which is this, assigning to itself).
2658     * @param x in the doubled coordinate space, the x position that should become 0 x in the result; can be negative
2659     * @param y in the doubled coordinate space, the y position that should become 0 y in the result; can be negative
2660     * @return this for chaining
2661     */
2662    public GreasedRegion zoom(int x, int y)
2663    {
2664        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0)
2665            return this;
2666        x = -x;
2667        y = -y;
2668        int
2669                width2 = width + 1 >>> 1, ySections2 = ySections + 1 >>> 1,
2670                start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, width + x) - start,
2671                //tall = (Math.min(height, height + y) - Math.max(0, y)) + 63 >> 6,
2672                jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
2673                originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump),
2674                oddX = (x & 1), oddY = (y & 1);
2675        long[] data2 = new long[width * ySections];
2676
2677        long prev, tmp, yEndMask2 = -1L >>> (64 - ((height + 1 >>> 1) & 63));
2678        if (x < 0) {
2679            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i <= ySections2 && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2680                for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
2681                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2682                }
2683            }
2684        } else if (x > 0) {
2685            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i <= ySections2 && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2686                for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
2687                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2688                }
2689            }
2690        } else {
2691            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i <= ySections2 && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2692                for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
2693                    data2[j * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2694                }
2695            }
2696        }
2697
2698        if(lily < 0) {
2699            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
2700                prev = 0L;
2701                for (int j = ySections2; j >= 0; j--) {
2702                    tmp = prev;
2703                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
2704                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
2705                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2706                }
2707            }
2708        }
2709        else if(lily > 0) {
2710            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
2711                prev = 0L;
2712                for (int j = 0; j < ySections2; j++) {
2713                    tmp = prev;
2714                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
2715                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
2716                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2717                }
2718            }
2719        }
2720
2721
2722        if(ySections2 > 0 && yEndMask2 != -1) {
2723            for (int a = ySections2 - 1; a < data2.length; a += ySections) {
2724                data2[a] &= yEndMask2;
2725                if(ySections2 < ySections)
2726                    data2[a+1] = 0L;
2727            }
2728        }
2729        for (int i = 0; i < width2; i++) {
2730            for (int j = 0; j < ySections2; j++) {
2731                prev = data2[i * ySections + j];
2732                tmp = prev >>> 32;
2733                prev &= 0xFFFFFFFFL;
2734                prev = (prev | (prev << 16)) & 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
2735                prev = (prev | (prev << 8)) & 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
2736                prev = (prev | (prev << 4)) & 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
2737                prev = (prev | (prev << 2)) & 0x3333333333333333L;
2738                prev = (prev | (prev << 1)) & 0x5555555555555555L;
2739                prev <<= oddY;
2740                if(oddX == 1) {
2741                    if (i * 2 + 1 < width)
2742                        data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + ySections] = prev;
2743                    if (i * 2 < width)
2744                        data[(i * ySections + j) * 2] = 0L;
2745                }
2746                else
2747                {
2748                    if (i * 2 < width)
2749                        data[(i * ySections + j) * 2] = prev;
2750                    if (i * 2 + 1 < width)
2751                        data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + ySections] = 0L;
2752                }
2753                if(j * 2 + 1 < ySections) {
2754                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 16)) & 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
2755                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 8)) & 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
2756                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 4)) & 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
2757                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 2)) & 0x3333333333333333L;
2758                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 1)) & 0x5555555555555555L;
2759                    tmp <<= oddY;
2760                    if(oddX == 1) {
2761                        if (i * 2 + 1 < width)
2762                            data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + ySections + 1] = tmp;
2763                        if (i * 2 < width)
2764                            data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + 1] = 0L;
2765                    }
2766                    else
2767                    {
2768                        if (i * 2 < width)
2769                            data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + 1] = tmp;
2770                        if (i * 2 + 1 < width)
2771                            data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + ySections + 1] = 0L;
2772                    }
2773                }
2774            }
2775        }
2776
2777        if(yEndMask != -1) {
2778            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2779                data[a] &= yEndMask;
2780            }
2781        }
2782        tallied = false;
2783        return this;
2784    }

2786    /**
2787     * Takes the pairs of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion that are separated by exactly one cell in an orthogonal line,
2788     * and changes the gap cells to "on" as well.
2789     * <br>
2790     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
2791     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
2792     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
2793     * @return this for chaining
2794     */
2795    public GreasedRegion connect()
2796    {
2797        if(width < 2 || ySections == 0)
2798            return this;
2799
2800        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
2801        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
2802        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
2803            next[a] |= ((data[a] << 1) & (data[a] >>> 1)) | data[a+ySections];
2804            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= ((data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) & (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1)) | data[(width-2) *ySections+a];
2805
2806            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2807                next[i] |= ((data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1)) | (data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections]);
2808            }
2809
2810            if(a > 0) {
2811                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2812                    next[i] |= (data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i] >>> 1);
2813                }
2814            }
2815            else
2816            {
2817                for (int i = ySections; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2818                    next[i] |= (data[i] >>> 1 & 1L);
2819                }
2820            }
2821
2822            if(a < ySections - 1) {
2823                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2824                    next[i] |= (data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i] << 1);
2825                }
2826            }
2827            else
2828            {
2829                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2830                    next[i] |= (data[i] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L);
2831                }
2832
2833            }
2834        }
2835
2836        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2837            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
2838                next[a] &= yEndMask;
2839            }
2840        }
2841        data = next;
2842        tallied = false;
2843        return this;
2844    }

2846    /**
2847     * Takes the pairs of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion that are separated by exactly one cell in an orthogonal or
2848     * diagonal line, and changes the gap cells to "on" as well.
2849     * <br>
2850     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
2851     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
2852     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
2853     * @return this for chaining
2854     */
2855    public GreasedRegion connect8way()
2856    {
2857        if(width < 2 || ySections == 0)
2858            return this;
2859
2860        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
2861        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
2862        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
2863            next[a] |= ((data[a] << 1) & (data[a] >>> 1)) | data[a+ySections] | (data[a+ySections] << 1) | (data[a+ySections] >>> 1);
2864            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= ((data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) & (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1))
2865                    | data[(width-2) *ySections+a] | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] >>> 1);
2866
2867            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2868                next[i] |= ((data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1)) | (data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections])
2869                        | ((data[i - ySections] << 1) & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1))
2870                        | ((data[i + ySections] << 1) & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1));
2871            }
2872
2873            if(a > 0) {
2874                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2875                    next[i] |= ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i] >>> 1)) |
2876                            ((data[i - ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1)) |
2877                            ((data[i + ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1));
2878                }
2879            }
2880            else
2881            {
2882                for (int i = ySections; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2883                    next[i] |= (data[i] >>> 1 & 1L) | (data[i - ySections] >>> 1 & 1L) | (data[i + ySections] >>> 1 & 1L);
2884                }
2885            }
2886
2887            if(a < ySections - 1) {
2888                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2889                    next[i] |= ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i] << 1)) |
2890                            ((data[i - ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i + ySections] << 1)) |
2891                            ((data[i + ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i - ySections] << 1)) ;
2892                }
2893            }
2894            else
2895            {
2896                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2897                    next[i] |= (data[i] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L)
2898                            | (data[i - ySections] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L) | (data[i + ySections] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L);
2899                }
2900
2901            }
2902        }
2903
2904        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2905            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
2906                next[a] &= yEndMask;
2907            }
2908        }
2909        data = next;
2910        tallied = false;
2911        return this;
2912    }
2913    /**
2914     * Takes the pairs of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion that are separated by exactly one cell in an orthogonal or
2915     * diagonal line, and changes the gap cells to "on" as well. As a special case, this requires diagonals to either
2916     * have no "on" cells adjacent along the perpendicular diagonal, or both cells on that perpendicular diagonal need
2917     * to be "on." This is useful to counteract some less-desirable behavior of {@link #connect8way()}, where a right
2918     * angle would always get the inner corners filled because it was considered a diagonal.
2919     * <br>
2920     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
2921     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
2922     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
2923     * @return this for chaining
2924     */
2925    public GreasedRegion connectLines()
2926    {
2927        if(width < 2 || ySections == 0)
2928            return this;
2929
2930        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
2931        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
2932        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
2933            next[a] |= ((data[a] << 1) & (data[a] >>> 1)) | data[a+ySections] | (data[a+ySections] << 1) | (data[a+ySections] >>> 1);
2934            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= ((data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) & (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1))
2935                    | data[(width-2) *ySections+a] | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] >>> 1);
2936
2937            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2938                next[i] |= ((data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1)) | (data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections])
2939                        | (((data[i - ySections] << 1) & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1))
2940                           ^ ((data[i + ySections] << 1) & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)));
2941            }
2942
2943            if(a > 0) {
2944                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2945                    next[i] |= ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i] >>> 1))
2946                            | (((data[i - ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1))
2947                               ^ ((data[i + ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)));
2948                }
2949            }
2950            else
2951            {
2952                for (int i = ySections; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2953                    next[i] |= (data[i] >>> 1 & 1L) | (data[i - ySections] >>> 1 & 1L) | (data[i + ySections] >>> 1 & 1L);
2954                }
2955            }
2956
2957            if(a < ySections - 1) {
2958                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2959                    next[i] |= ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i] << 1))
2960                            | (((data[i - ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i + ySections] << 1))
2961                               ^ ((data[i + ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i - ySections] << 1)));
2962                }
2963            }
2964            else
2965            {
2966                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2967                    next[i] |= (data[i] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L)
2968                            | (data[i - ySections] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L) | (data[i + ySections] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L);
2969                }
2970
2971            }
2972        }
2973
2974        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2975            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
2976                next[a] &= yEndMask;
2977            }
2978        }
2979        data = next;
2980        tallied = false;
2981        return this;
2982    }
2983
2984    /**
2985     * Like {@link #retract()}, this reduces the width of thick areas of this GreasedRegion, but thin() will not remove
2986     * areas that would be identical in a subsequent call to retract(), such as if the area would be eliminated. This
2987     * is useful primarily for adjusting areas so they do not exceed a width of 2 cells, though their length (the longer
2988     * of the two dimensions) will be unaffected by this. Especially wide, irregularly-shaped areas may have unintended
2989     * appearances if you call this repeatedly or use {@link #thinFully()}; consider using this sparingly, or primarily
2990     * when an area has just gotten thicker than desired.
2991     * <br>
2992     * This currently uses 4-way adjacency, but had previously used 8-way; if you want the behavior this previously had,
2993     * you can use {@link #thin8way()}, but it may be a good idea to try this method as well (some of the old behavior
2994     * had problems where it yielded significantly larger minimum widths in some areas).
2995     * @return this for chaining
2996     */
2997    public GreasedRegion thin()
2998    {
2999        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
3000            return this;
3001        GreasedRegion c1 = new GreasedRegion(this).retract(),
3002                c2 = new GreasedRegion(c1).expand().xor(this).expand().and(this);
3003        remake(c1).or(c2);
3004        /*
3005        System.out.println("\n\nc1:\n" + c1.toString() + "\n");
3006        System.out.println("\n\nc2:\n" + c2.toString() + "\n");
3007        System.out.println("\n\nthis:\n" + toString() + "\n");
3008        */
3009        return this;
3010    }
3011
3012    /**
3013     * Calls {@link #thin()} repeatedly, until the result is unchanged from the last call. Consider using the idiom
3014     * {@code expand8way().retract().thinFully()} to help change a possibly-strange appearance when the GreasedRegion
3015     * this is called on touches the edges of the grid. In general, this method is likely to go too far when it tries to
3016     * thin a round or irregular area, and this often results in many diagonal lines spanning the formerly-thick area.
3017     * <br>
3018     * This currently uses 4-way adjacency, but had previously used 8-way; if you want the behavior this previously had,
3019     * you can use {@link #thinFully8way()}, but it may be a good idea to try this method as well (some of the old
3020     * behavior had problems where it yielded significantly larger minimum widths in some areas).
3021     * @return this for chaining
3022     */
3023    public GreasedRegion thinFully()
3024    {
3025        while (size() != thin().size());
3026        return this;
3027    }

3030    /**
3031     * Like {@link #retract8way()}, this reduces the width of thick areas of this GreasedRegion, but thin8way() will not
3032     * remove areas that would be identical in a subsequent call to retract8way(), such as if the area would be
3033     * eliminated. This is useful primarily for adjusting areas so they do not exceed a width of 2 cells, though their
3034     * length (the longer of the two dimensions) will be unaffected by this. Especially wide, irregularly-shaped areas
3035     * may have unintended appearances if you call this repeatedly or use {@link #thinFully8way()}; consider using this
3036     * sparingly, or primarily when an area has just gotten thicker than desired.
3037     * <br>
3038     * This method was called {@link #thin()}, but now that name refers to a variant that uses 4-way adjacency.
3039     * @return this for chaining
3040     */
3041    public GreasedRegion thin8way()
3042    {
3043        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
3044            return this;
3045        GreasedRegion c1 = new GreasedRegion(this).retract8way(),
3046                c2 = new GreasedRegion(c1).expand8way().xor(this).expand8way().and(this);
3047        remake(c1).or(c2);
3048        return this;
3049    }
3050
3051    /**
3052     * Calls {@link #thin8way()} repeatedly, until the result is unchanged from the last call. Consider using the idiom
3053     * {@code expand8way().retract().thinFully8way()} to help change a strange appearance when the GreasedRegion this is
3054     * called on touches the edges of the grid. In general, this method is likely to go too far when it tries to thin a
3055     * round or irregular area, and this often results in many diagonal lines spanning the formerly-thick area.
3056     * <br>
3057     * This method was called {@link #thinFully()}, but now that name refers to a variant that uses 4-way adjacency.
3058     * @return this for chaining
3059     */
3060    public GreasedRegion thinFully8way()
3061    {
3062        while (size() != thin8way().size());
3063        return this;
3064    }

3067    /**
3068     * Removes "on" cells that are orthogonally adjacent to other "on" cells, keeping at least one cell in a group "on."
3069     * Uses a "checkerboard" pattern to determine which cells to turn  off, with all cells that would be black on a
3070     * checkerboard turned off and all others kept as-is.
3071     * @return this for chaining
3072     */
3073    public GreasedRegion disperse()
3074    {
3075        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0)
3076            return this;
3077        long mask = 0x5555555555555555L;
3078        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
3079            for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
3080                data[j] &= mask;
3081            }
3082            mask = ~mask;
3083        }
3084        tallied = false;
3085        return this;
3086    }
3087    /**
3088     * Removes "on" cells that are 8-way adjacent to other "on" cells, keeping at least one cell in a group "on."
3089     * Uses a "grid-like" pattern to determine which cells to turn off, with all cells with even x and even y kept as-is
3090     * but all other cells (with either or both odd x or odd y) turned off.
3091     * @return this for chaining
3092     */
3093    public GreasedRegion disperse8way()
3094    {
3095        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0)
3096            return this;
3097        int len = data.length;
3098        long mask = 0x5555555555555555L;
3099        for (int j = 0; j < len - 1; j += 2) {
3100            data[j] &= mask;
3101            data[j+1] = 0;
3102        }
3103        tallied = false;
3104        return this;
3105    }
3106    /**
3107     * Removes "on" cells that are nearby other "on" cells, with a random factor to which bits are actually turned off
3108     * that still ensures exactly half of the bits are kept as-is (the one exception is when height is an odd number,
3109     * which makes the bottom row slightly random).
3110     * @param random the RNG used for a random factor
3111     * @return this for chaining
3112     */
3113    public GreasedRegion disperseRandom(RandomnessSource random)
3114    {
3115        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0)
3116            return this;
3117        int len = data.length;
3118        for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
3119            data[j] &= randomInterleave(random);
3120        }
3121        tallied = false;
3122        return this;
3123    }
3124    /**
3125     * Generates a random 64-bit long with a number of '1' bits (Hamming weight) equal on average to bitCount.
3126     * For example, calling this with a parameter of 32 will be equivalent to calling nextLong() on the given
3127     * RandomnessSource, which could be an {@link RNG} or any RandomnessSource with good 64-bit generation quality.
3128     * Calling this with a parameter of 16 will have on average 16 of the 64 bits in the returned long set to '1',
3129     * distributed pseudo-randomly, while a parameter of 47 will have on average 47 bits set. This can be useful for
3130     * certain code that uses bits to represent data but needs a different ratio of set bits to unset bits than 1:1.
3131     * <br>
3132     * The parameter {@code random} can be an object like a {@link DiverRNG}, an {@link RNG} backed by a
3133     * well-distributed RandomnessSource like its default, DiverRNG, a {@link GWTRNG} (especially if you target GWT,
3134     * where it will perform much better than most alternatives), or any of various other RandomnessSource
3135     * implementations that distribute bits well for {@link RandomnessSource#nextLong()}, but should not be
3136     * intentionally-biased RNGs like {@link DharmaRNG} or {@link EditRNG}, nor double-based QRNGs like
3137     * {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} or {@link SobolQRNG}.
3138     * @param random used to determine random factors; likely to be an {@link RNG}, {@link DiverRNG}, or {@link GWTRNG}
3139     * @param bitCount an int, only considered if between 0 and 64, that is the average number of bits to set
3140     * @return a 64-bit long that, on average, should have bitCount bits set to 1, potentially anywhere in the long
3141     */
3142    public static long approximateBits(RandomnessSource random, int bitCount) {
3143        if (bitCount <= 0)
3144            return 0L;
3145        if (bitCount >= 64)
3146            return -1L;
3147        if (bitCount == 32)
3148            return random.nextLong();
3149        boolean high = bitCount > 32;
3150        int altered = (high ? 64 - bitCount : bitCount), lsb = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(altered);
3151        long data = random.nextLong();
3152        for (int i = lsb << 1; i <= 16; i <<= 1) {
3153            if ((altered & i) == 0)
3154                data &= random.nextLong();
3155            else
3156                data |= random.nextLong();
3157        }
3158        return high ? ~(random.nextLong() & data) : (random.nextLong() & data);
3159    }
3160
3161    /**
3162     * Gets a somewhat-random long with exactly 32 bits set; in each pair of bits starting at bit 0 and bit 1, then bit
3163     * 2 and bit 3, up to bit 62 and bit 3, one bit will be 1 and one bit will be 0 in each pair.
3164     * <br>
3165     * Not exactly general-use; meant for generating data for GreasedRegion.
3166     * @return a random long with 32 "1" bits, distributed so exactly one bit is "1" for each pair of bits
3167     */
3168    public static long randomInterleave(RandomnessSource random) {
3169        long bits = random.nextLong() & 0xFFFFFFFFL, ib = ~bits & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
3170        bits |= (bits << 16);
3171        ib |= (ib << 16);
3172        bits &= 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
3173        ib &= 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
3174        bits |= (bits << 8);
3175        ib |= (ib << 8);
3176        bits &= 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
3177        ib &= 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
3178        bits |= (bits << 4);
3179        ib |= (ib << 4);
3180        bits &= 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
3181        ib &= 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
3182        bits |= (bits << 2);
3183        ib |= (ib << 2);
3184        bits &= 0x3333333333333333L;
3185        ib &= 0x3333333333333333L;
3186        bits |= (bits << 1);
3187        ib |= (ib << 1);
3188        bits &= 0x5555555555555555L;
3189        ib &= 0x5555555555555555L;
3190        return (bits | (ib << 1));
3191    }

3193    /**
3194     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and expands them by one cell in the 4 orthogonal directions, making
3195     * each "on" cell take up a plus-shaped area that may overlap with other "on" cells (which is just a normal "on"
3196     * cell then).
3197     * <br>
3198     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3199     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3200     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3201     * @return this for chaining
3202     */
3203    public GreasedRegion expand()
3204    {
3205        if(width < 2 || ySections == 0)
3206            return this;
3207
3208        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3209        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
3210        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
3211            next[a] |= (data[a] << 1) | (data[a] >>> 1) | data[a+ySections];
3212            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1) | data[(width-2) *ySections+a];
3213
3214            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3215                next[i] |= (data[i] << 1) | (data[i] >>> 1) | data[i - ySections] | data[i + ySections];
3216            }
3217
3218            if(a > 0) {
3219                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3220                    next[i] |= (data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63;
3221                }
3222            }
3223
3224            if(a < ySections - 1) {
3225                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3226                    next[i] |= (data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63;
3227                }
3228            }
3229        }
3230
3231        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
3232            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3233                next[a] &= yEndMask;
3234            }
3235        }
3236        data = next;
3237        tallied = false;
3238        return this;
3239    }
3240    /**
3241     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and expands them by amount cells in the 4 orthogonal directions,
3242     * making each "on" cell take up a plus-shaped area that may overlap with other "on" cells (which is just a normal
3243     * "on" cell then).
3244     * <br>
3245     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3246     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3247     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3248     * @return this for chaining
3249     */
3250    @Override
3251    public GreasedRegion expand(int amount)
3252    {
3253        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3254            expand();
3255        }
3256        return this;
3257    }
3258    /**
3259     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and produces amount GreasedRegions, each one expanded by 1 cell in
3260     * the 4 orthogonal directions relative to the previous GreasedRegion, making each "on" cell take up a plus-shaped
3261     * area that may overlap with other "on" cells (which is just a normal "on" cell then). This returns an array of
3262     * GreasedRegions with progressively greater expansions, and does not modify this GreasedRegion.
3263     * <br>
3264     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3265     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3266     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3267     * @return an array of new GreasedRegions, length == amount, where each one is expanded by 1 relative to the last
3268     */
3269    public GreasedRegion[] expandSeries(int amount)
3270    {
3271        if(amount <= 0) return new GreasedRegion[0];
3272        GreasedRegion[] regions = new GreasedRegion[amount];
3273        GreasedRegion temp = new GreasedRegion(this);
3274        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3275            regions[i] = new GreasedRegion(temp.expand());
3276        }
3277        return regions;
3278    }

3284        while (temp.size() != temp.expand().size()) {
3285            regions.add(new GreasedRegion(temp));

3289    /**
3290     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and expands them by one cell in the 4 orthogonal directions, producing
3291     * a diamoond shape, then removes the original area before expansion, producing only the cells that were "off" in
3292     * this and within 1 cell (orthogonal-only) of an "on" cell. This method is similar to {@link #surface()}, but
3293     * surface finds cells inside the current GreasedRegion, while fringe finds cells outside it.
3294     * <br>
3295     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3296     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3297     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time. The surface and fringe methods do allocate one
3298     * temporary GreasedRegion to store the original before modification, but the others generally don't.
3299     * @return this for chaining
3300     */
3301    public GreasedRegion fringe()
3302    {
3303        GreasedRegion cpy = new GreasedRegion(this);
3304        expand();
3305        return andNot(cpy);
3306    }
3307    /**
3308     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and expands them by amount cells in the 4 orthogonal directions
3309     * (iteratively, producing a diamond shape), then removes the original area before expansion, producing only the
3310     * cells that were "off" in this and within amount cells (orthogonal-only) of an "on" cell. This method is similar
3311     * to {@link #surface()}, but surface finds cells inside the current GreasedRegion, while fringe finds cells outside
3312     * it.
3313     * <br>
3314     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3315     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3316     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time. The surface and fringe methods do allocate one
3317     * temporary GreasedRegion to store the original before modification, but the others generally don't.
3318     * @return this for chaining
3319     */
3320
3321    public GreasedRegion fringe(int amount)
3322    {
3323        GreasedRegion cpy = new GreasedRegion(this);
3324        expand(amount);
3325        return andNot(cpy);
3326    }

3328    /**
3329     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and produces amount GreasedRegions, each one expanded by 1 cell in
3330     * the 4 orthogonal directions relative to the previous GreasedRegion, making each "on" cell take up a diamond-
3331     * shaped area. After producing the expansions, this removes the previous GreasedRegion from the next GreasedRegion
3332     * in the array, making each "fringe" in the series have 1 "thickness," which can be useful for finding which layer
3333     * of expansion a cell lies in. This returns an array of GreasedRegions with progressively greater expansions
3334     * without the cells of this GreasedRegion, and does not modify this GreasedRegion.
3335     * <br>
3336     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3337     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3338     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3339     * @return an array of new GreasedRegions, length == amount, where each one is a 1-depth fringe pushed further out from this
3340     */
3341    public GreasedRegion[] fringeSeries(int amount)
3342    {
3343        if(amount <= 0) return new GreasedRegion[0];
3344        GreasedRegion[] regions = new GreasedRegion[amount];
3345        GreasedRegion temp = new GreasedRegion(this);
3346        regions[0] = new GreasedRegion(temp);
3347        for (int i = 1; i < amount; i++) {
3348            regions[i] = new GreasedRegion(temp.expand());
3349        }
3350        for (int i = 0; i < amount - 1; i++) {
3351            regions[i].xor(regions[i + 1]);
3352        }
3353        regions[amount - 1].fringe();
3354        return regions;
3355    }
3356    public ArrayList<GreasedRegion> fringeSeriesToLimit()
3357    {
3358        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> regions = expandSeriesToLimit();
3359        for (int i = regions.size() - 1; i > 0; i--) {
3360            regions.get(i).xor(regions.get(i-1));
3361        }
3362        regions.get(0).xor(this);
3363        return regions;
3364    }

3366    /**
3367     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and retracts them by one cell in the 4 orthogonal directions,
3368     * making each "on" cell that was orthogonally adjacent to an "off" cell into an "off" cell.
3369     * <br>
3370     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3371     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3372     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3373     * @return this for chaining
3374     */
3375    public GreasedRegion retract()
3376    {
3377        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
3378            return this;
3379
3380        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3381        System.arraycopy(data, ySections, next, ySections, (width - 2) * ySections);
3382        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
3383            if(a > 0 && a < ySections - 1) {
3384                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3385                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3386                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63))
3387                            & data[i - ySections]
3388                            & data[i + ySections];
3389                }
3390            }
3391            else if(a > 0) {
3392                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3393                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3394                            & (data[i] >>> 1)
3395                            & data[i - ySections]
3396                            & data[i + ySections];
3397                }
3398            }
3399            else if(a < ySections - 1) {
3400                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3401                    next[i] &= (data[i] << 1)
3402                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63))
3403                            & data[i - ySections]
3404                            & data[i + ySections];
3405                }
3406            }
3407            else // only the case when ySections == 1
3408            {
3409                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3410                    next[i] &= (data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1) & data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections];
3411                }
3412            }
3413        }
3414
3415        if(yEndMask != -1) {
3416            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3417                next[a] &= yEndMask;
3418            }
3419        }
3420        data = next;
3421        tallied = false;
3422        return this;
3423    }

3428     * into an "off" cell.
3429     * <br>
3430     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3431     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3432     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.

3434     */

3436    {
3437        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {

3475    public GreasedRegion[] surfaceSeries(int amount)
3476    {
3477        if(amount <= 0) return new GreasedRegion[0];
3478        GreasedRegion[] regions = new GreasedRegion[amount];
3479        GreasedRegion temp = new GreasedRegion(this);
3480        regions[0] = new GreasedRegion(temp);
3481        for (int i = 1; i < amount; i++) {
3482            regions[i] = new GreasedRegion(temp.retract());
3483        }
3484        for (int i = 0; i < amount - 1; i++) {

3491    public ArrayList<GreasedRegion> surfaceSeriesToLimit()
3492    {
3493        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> regions = retractSeriesToLimit();
3494        if(regions.isEmpty())
3495            return regions;
3496        regions.add(0, regions.get(0).copy().xor(this));
3497        for (int i = 1; i < regions.size() - 1; i++) {
3498            regions.get(i).xor(regions.get(i+1));
3499        }
3500        return regions;
3501    }
3502    public GreasedRegion expand8way()
3503    {
3504        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0)
3505            return this;
3506
3507        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3508        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
3509        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
3510            next[a] |= (data[a] << 1) | (data[a] >>> 1)
3511                    | data[a+ySections] | (data[a+ySections] << 1) | (data[a+ySections] >>> 1);
3512            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1)
3513                    | data[(width-2) *ySections+a] | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] >>> 1);
3514
3515            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3516                next[i] |= (data[i] << 1) | (data[i] >>> 1)
3517                        | data[i - ySections] | (data[i - ySections] << 1) | (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)
3518                        | data[i + ySections] | (data[i + ySections] << 1) | (data[i + ySections] >>> 1);
3519            }
3520
3521            if(a > 0) {
3522                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3523                    next[i] |= ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63) |
3524                            ((data[i - ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63) |
3525                            ((data[i + ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63);
3526                }
3527            }
3528
3529            if(a < ySections - 1) {
3530                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3531                    next[i] |= ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63) |
3532                            ((data[i - ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63) |
3533                            ((data[i + ySections+ 1] & 1L) << 63);
3534                }
3535            }
3536        }
3537
3538        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
3539            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3540                next[a] &= yEndMask;
3541            }
3542        }
3543        data = next;
3544        tallied = false;
3545        return this;
3546    }

3557    public GreasedRegion[] expandSeries8way(int amount)
3558    {
3559        if(amount <= 0) return new GreasedRegion[0];
3560        GreasedRegion[] regions = new GreasedRegion[amount];
3561        GreasedRegion temp = new GreasedRegion(this);
3562        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3563            regions[i] = new GreasedRegion(temp.expand8way());
3564        }
3565        return regions;
3566    }

3602        regions[amount - 1].fringe8way();

3615    public GreasedRegion retract8way()
3616    {
3617        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
3618            return this;
3619
3620        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3621        System.arraycopy(data, ySections, next, ySections, (width - 2) * ySections);
3622        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
3623            if(a > 0 && a < ySections - 1) {
3624                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3625                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3626                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63))
3627                            & data[i - ySections]
3628                            & data[i + ySections]
3629                            & ((data[i - ySections] << 1) | ((data[i - 1 - ySections] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3630                            & ((data[i + ySections] << 1) | ((data[i - 1 + ySections] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3631                            & ((data[i - ySections] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1 - ySections] & 1L) << 63))
3632                            & ((data[i + ySections] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1 + ySections] & 1L) << 63));
3633                }
3634            }
3635            else if(a > 0) {
3636                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3637                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3638                            & (data[i] >>> 1)
3639                            & data[i - ySections]
3640                            & data[i + ySections]
3641                            & ((data[i - ySections] << 1) | ((data[i - 1 - ySections] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3642                            & ((data[i + ySections] << 1) | ((data[i - 1 + ySections] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3643                            & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)
3644                            & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1);
3645                }
3646            }
3647            else if(a < ySections - 1) {
3648                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3649                    next[i] &= (data[i] << 1)
3650                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63))
3651                            & data[i - ySections]
3652                            & data[i + ySections]
3653                            & (data[i - ySections] << 1)
3654                            & (data[i + ySections] << 1)
3655                            & ((data[i - ySections] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1 - ySections] & 1L) << 63))
3656                            & ((data[i + ySections] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1 + ySections] & 1L) << 63));
3657                }
3658            }
3659            else // only the case when ySections == 1
3660            {
3661                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3662                    next[i] &= (data[i] << 1)
3663                            & (data[i] >>> 1)
3664                            & data[i - ySections]
3665                            & data[i + ySections]
3666                            & (data[i - ySections] << 1)
3667                            & (data[i + ySections] << 1)
3668                            & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)
3669                            & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1);
3670                }
3671            }
3672        }
3673
3674        if(yEndMask != -1) {
3675            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3676                next[a] &= yEndMask;
3677            }
3678        }
3679        data = next;
3680        tallied = false;
3681        return this;
3682    }

3684    public GreasedRegion retract8way(int amount)
3685    {
3686        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3687            retract8way();
3688        }
3689        return this;
3690    }

3733        }

3740    public ArrayList<GreasedRegion> surfaceSeriesToLimit8way()
3741    {

3743        if(regions.isEmpty())
3744            return regions;
3745        regions.add(0, regions.get(0).copy().xor(this));
3746        for (int i = 1; i < regions.size() - 1; i++) {
3747            regions.get(i).xor(regions.get(i+1));
3748        }
