3751    public GreasedRegion flood(GreasedRegion bounds)
3752    {
3753        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0 || bounds == null || bounds.width < 2 || bounds.ySections <= 0)
3754            return this;
3755
3756        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3757        for (int a = 0; a < ySections && a < bounds.ySections; a++) {
3758            next[a] |= (data[a] |(data[a] << 1) | (data[a] >>> 1) | data[a+ySections]) & bounds.data[a];
3759            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1)
3760                    | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1) | data[(width-2) *ySections+a]) & bounds.data[(width-1)*bounds.ySections+a];
3761
3762            for (int i = ySections+a, j = bounds.ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections &&
3763                    j < (bounds.width - 1) * bounds.ySections; i+= ySections, j+= bounds.ySections) {
3764                next[i] |= (data[i] | (data[i] << 1) | (data[i] >>> 1) | data[i - ySections] | data[i + ySections]) & bounds.data[j];
3765            }
3766
3767            if(a > 0) {
3768                for (int i = ySections+a, j = bounds.ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections && j < (bounds.width-1) * bounds.ySections;
3769                     i+= ySections, j += bounds.ySections) {
3770                    next[i] |= (data[i] | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63)) & bounds.data[j];
3771                }
3772            }
3773
3774            if(a < ySections - 1 && a < bounds.ySections - 1) {
3775                for (int i = ySections+a, j = bounds.ySections+a;
3776                     i < (width-1) * ySections && j < (bounds.width-1) * bounds.ySections; i+= ySections, j += bounds.ySections) {
3777                    next[i] |= (data[i] | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63)) & bounds.data[j];
3778                }
3779            }
3780        }
3781
3782        if(yEndMask != -1 && bounds.yEndMask != -1) {
3783            if(ySections == bounds.ySections) {
3784                long mask = ((yEndMask >>> 1) <= (bounds.yEndMask >>> 1))
3785                        ? yEndMask : bounds.yEndMask;
3786                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3787                    next[a] &= mask;
3788                }
3789            }
3790            else if(ySections < bounds.ySections) {
3791                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3792                    next[a] &= yEndMask;
3793                }
3794            }
3795            else {
3796                for (int a = bounds.ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3797                    next[a] &= bounds.yEndMask;
3798                }
3799            }
3800        }
3801        data = next;
3802        tallied = false;
3803        return this;
3804    }

3808        int ct = size(), ct2;
3809        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3810            flood(bounds);
3811            if(ct == (ct2 = size()))
3812                break;
3813            else
3814                ct = ct2;
3815
3816        }
3817        return this;
3818    }

3858    public GreasedRegion flood8way(GreasedRegion bounds)
3859    {
3860        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0 || bounds == null || bounds.width < 2 || bounds.ySections <= 0)
3861            return this;
3862
3863        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3864        for (int a = 0; a < ySections && a < bounds.ySections; a++) {
3865            next[a] |= (data[a] | (data[a] << 1) | (data[a] >>> 1)
3866                    | data[a+ySections] | (data[a+ySections] << 1) | (data[a+ySections] >>> 1)) & bounds.data[a];
3867            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= (data[(width-1)*ySections+a]
3868                    | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1)
3869                    | data[(width-2) *ySections+a] | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] >>> 1))
3870                    & bounds.data[(width-1)*bounds.ySections+a];
3871
3872            for (int i = ySections+a, j = bounds.ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections &&
3873                    j < (bounds.width - 1) * bounds.ySections; i+= ySections, j+= bounds.ySections) {
3874                next[i] |= (data[i] | (data[i] << 1) | (data[i] >>> 1)
3875                        | data[i - ySections] | (data[i - ySections] << 1) | (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)
3876                        | data[i + ySections] | (data[i + ySections] << 1) | (data[i + ySections] >>> 1))
3877                        & bounds.data[j];
3878            }
3879
3880            if(a > 0) {
3881                for (int i = ySections+a, j = bounds.ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections && j < (bounds.width-1) * bounds.ySections;
3882                     i+= ySections, j += bounds.ySections) {
3883                    next[i] |= (data[i] | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63) |
3884                            ((data[i - ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63) |
3885                            ((data[i + ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63)) & bounds.data[j];
3886                }
3887            }
3888
3889            if(a < ySections - 1 && a < bounds.ySections - 1) {
3890                for (int i = ySections+a, j = bounds.ySections+a;
3891                     i < (width-1) * ySections && j < (bounds.width-1) * bounds.ySections; i+= ySections, j += bounds.ySections) {
3892                    next[i] |= (data[i] | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63) |
3893                            ((data[i - ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63) |
3894                            ((data[i + ySections+ 1] & 1L) << 63)) & bounds.data[j];
3895                }
3896            }
3897        }
3898
3899        if(yEndMask != -1 && bounds.yEndMask != -1) {
3900            if(ySections == bounds.ySections) {
3901                long mask = ((yEndMask >>> 1) <= (bounds.yEndMask >>> 1))
3902                        ? yEndMask : bounds.yEndMask;
3903                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3904                    next[a] &= mask;
3905                }
3906            }
3907            else if(ySections < bounds.ySections) {
3908                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3909                    next[a] &= yEndMask;
3910                }
3911            }
3912            else {
3913                for (int a = bounds.ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3914                    next[a] &= bounds.yEndMask;
3915                }
3916            }
3917        }
3918        data = next;
3919        tallied = false;
3920        return this;
3921    }

3971    public GreasedRegion spill(GreasedRegion bounds, int volume, IRNG rng)
3972    {
3973        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0 || bounds == null || bounds.width < 2 || bounds.ySections <= 0)
3974            return this;
3975        int current = size();
3976        if(current >= volume)
3977            return this;
3978        GreasedRegion t = new GreasedRegion(this).notAnd(bounds);
3979        long[] b2 = new long[t.data.length];
3980        System.arraycopy(t.data, 0, b2, 0, b2.length);
3981        t.remake(this).fringe().and(bounds).tally();
3982        if(t.ct <= 0)
3983            return this;
3984        Coord c;
3985        int x, y, p;
3986        for (int i = current; i < volume; i++) {
3987            c = t.singleRandom(rng);
3988            x = c.x;
3989            y = c.y;
3990            if(data[p = x * ySections + (y >> 6)] != (data[p] |= 1L << (y & 63)))
3991            {
3992                counts[p]++;
3993                for (int j = p+1; j < data.length; j++) {
3994                    if(counts[j] > 0) ++counts[j];
3995                }
3996                ct++;
3997                t.data[p] &= ~(1L << (y & 63));
3998//                b2[p] &= ~(1L << (y & 63));
3999                if(x < width - 1 && (b2[p = (x+1) * ySections + (y >> 6)] & 1L << (y & 63)) != 0)
4000                {
4001                    t.data[p] |= 1L << (y & 63);
4002                }
4003                if(y < height - 1 && (b2[p = x * ySections + (y+1 >> 6)] & 1L << (y+1 & 63)) != 0)
4004                {
4005                    t.data[p] |= 1L << (y+1 & 63);
4006                }
4007                if(y > 0 && (b2[p = x * ySections + (y-1 >> 6)] & 1L << (y-1 & 63)) != 0)
4008                {
4009                    t.data[p] |= 1L << (y-1 & 63);
4010                }
4011                if(x > 0 && (b2[p = (x-1) * ySections + (y >> 6)] & 1L << (y & 63)) != 0)
4012                {
4013
4014                    t.data[p] |= 1L << (y & 63);
4015                }
4016                t.tally();
4017                if(t.ct <= 0) break;
4018            }
4019        }
4020        tallied = false;
4021        return this;
4022    }

4024    public GreasedRegion removeCorners()
4025    {
4026        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
4027            return this;
4028
4029        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
4030        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
4031        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
4032            if(a > 0 && a < ySections - 1) {
4033                next[a] &= (((data[a] << 1) | ((data[a - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4034                        & ((data[a] >>> 1) | ((data[a + 1] & 1L) << 63)));
4035                next[(width - 1) * ySections + a] &= (((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] << 1)
4036                        | ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4037                        & ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] >>> 1)
4038                        | ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a + 1] & 1L) << 63)));
4039                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4040                    next[i] &= (((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4041                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63)))
4042                            | (data[i - ySections]
4043                            & data[i + ySections]);
4044                }
4045            }
4046            else if(a > 0) {
4047                next[a] &= (((data[a] << 1) | ((data[a - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4048                        & (data[a] >>> 1));
4049                next[(width - 1) * ySections + a] &= (((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] << 1)
4050                        | ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4051                        & (data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] >>> 1));
4052                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4053                    next[i] &= (((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4054                            & (data[i] >>> 1))
4055                            | (data[i - ySections]
4056                            & data[i + ySections]);
4057                }
4058            }
4059            else if(a < ySections - 1) {
4060                next[a] &= ((data[a] << 1)
4061                        & ((data[a] >>> 1)
4062                        | ((data[a + 1] & 1L) << 63)));
4063                next[(width - 1) * ySections + a] &= ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] << 1)
4064                        & ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] >>> 1)
4065                        | ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a + 1] & 1L) << 63)));
4066                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4067                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1)
4068                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63)))
4069                            | (data[i - ySections]
4070                            & data[i + ySections]);
4071                }
4072            }
4073            else // only the case when ySections == 1
4074            {
4075                next[0] &= (data[0] << 1) & (data[0] >>> 1);
4076                next[width-1] &= (data[width-1] << 1) & (data[width-1] >>> 1);
4077                for (int i = 1+a; i < (width - 1); i++) {
4078                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1)) | (data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections]);
4079                }
4080            }
4081        }
4082
4083        if(yEndMask != -1) {
4084            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
4085                next[a] &= yEndMask;
4086            }
4087        }
4088        data = next;
4089        tallied = false;
4090        return this;
4091    }
4092
4093    /**
4094     * If this GreasedRegion stores multiple unconnected "on" areas, this finds each isolated area (areas that
4095     * are only adjacent diagonally are considered separate from each other) and returns it as an element in an
4096     * ArrayList of GreasedRegion, with one GreasedRegion per isolated area. Not to be confused with
4097     * {@link #split8way()}, which considers diagonally-adjacent cells as part of one region, while this method requires
4098     * cells to be orthogonally adjacent.
4099     * <br>
4100     * Useful when you have, for example, all the rooms in a dungeon with their connecting corridors removed, but want
4101     * to separate the rooms. You can get the aforementioned data assuming a bare dungeon called map using:
4102     * <br>
4103     * {@code GreasedRegion floors = new GreasedRegion(map, '.'),
4104     * rooms = floors.copy().retract8way().flood(floors, 2),
4105     * corridors = floors.copy().andNot(rooms),
4106     * doors = rooms.copy().and(corridors.copy().fringe());}
4107     * <br>
4108     * You can then get all rooms as separate regions with {@code List<GreasedRegion> apart = split(rooms);}, or
4109     * substitute {@code split(corridors)} to get the corridors. The room-finding technique works by shrinking floors
4110     * by a radius of 1 (8-way), which causes thin areas like corridors of 2 or less width to be removed, then
4111     * flood-filling the floors out from the area that produces by 2 cells (4-way this time) to restore the original
4112     * size of non-corridor areas (plus some extra to ensure odd shapes are kept). Corridors are obtained by removing
4113     * the rooms from floors. The example code also gets the doors (which overlap with rooms, not corridors) by finding
4114     * where the a room and a corridor are adjacent. This technique is used with some enhancements in the RoomFinder
4115     * class.
4116     * @see squidpony.squidgrid.mapping.RoomFinder for a class that uses this technique without exposing GreasedRegion
4117     * @return an ArrayList containing each unconnected area from packed as a GreasedRegion element
4118     */
4119    public ArrayList<GreasedRegion> split()
4120    {
4121        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> scattered = new ArrayList<>(32);
4122        int fst = firstTight();
4123        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this);
4124        while (fst >= 0) {
4125            GreasedRegion filled = new GreasedRegion(width, height).insert(fst).flood(remaining, width * height);
4126            scattered.add(filled);
4127            remaining.andNot(filled);
4128            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4129        }
4130        return scattered;
4131    }
4132    /**
4133     * If this GreasedRegion stores multiple unconnected "on" areas, this finds each isolated area (areas that
4134     * are only adjacent diagonally are considered <b>one area</b> with this) and returns it as an element in an
4135     * ArrayList of GreasedRegion, with one GreasedRegion per isolated area. This should not be confused with
4136     * {@link #split()}, which is almost identical except that split() considers only orthogonal connections, while this
4137     * method considers both orthogonal and diagonal connections between cells as joining an area.
4138     * <br>
4139     * Useful when you have, for example, all the rooms in a dungeon with their connecting corridors removed, but want
4140     * to separate the rooms. You can get the aforementioned data assuming a bare dungeon called map using:
4141     * <br>
4142     * {@code GreasedRegion floors = new GreasedRegion(map, '.'),
4143     * rooms = floors.copy().retract8way().flood(floors, 2),
4144     * corridors = floors.copy().andNot(rooms),
4145     * doors = rooms.copy().and(corridors.copy().fringe());}
4146     * <br>
4147     * You can then get all rooms as separate regions with {@code List<GreasedRegion> apart = split(rooms);}, or
4148     * substitute {@code split(corridors)} to get the corridors. The room-finding technique works by shrinking floors
4149     * by a radius of 1 (8-way), which causes thin areas like corridors of 2 or less width to be removed, then
4150     * flood-filling the floors out from the area that produces by 2 cells (4-way this time) to restore the original
4151     * size of non-corridor areas (plus some extra to ensure odd shapes are kept). Corridors are obtained by removing
4152     * the rooms from floors. The example code also gets the doors (which overlap with rooms, not corridors) by finding
4153     * where the a room and a corridor are adjacent. This technique is used with some enhancements in the RoomFinder
4154     * class.
4155     * @see squidpony.squidgrid.mapping.RoomFinder for a class that uses this technique without exposing GreasedRegion
4156     * @return an ArrayList containing each unconnected area from packed as a GreasedRegion element
4157     */
4158    public ArrayList<GreasedRegion> split8way()
4159    {
4160        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> scattered = new ArrayList<>(32);
4161        int fst = firstTight();
4162        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this);
4163        while (fst >= 0) {
4164            GreasedRegion filled = new GreasedRegion(width, height).insert(fst).flood8way(remaining, width * height);
4165            scattered.add(filled);
4166            remaining.andNot(filled);
4167            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4168        }
4169        return scattered;
4170    }

4172    /**
4173     * Finds the largest contiguous area of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and returns it; does not modify this
4174     * GreasedRegion. If there are multiple areas that are all equally large with no larger area, this returns the
4175     * region it checks first and still is largest (first determined by the same ordering {@link #nth(int)} takes).
4176     * This may return an empty GreasedRegion if there are no "on" cells, but it will never return null.
4177     * Here, contiguous means adjacent on an orthogonal direction, and this doesn't consider diagonally-connected cells
4178     * as contiguous unless they also have an orthogonal connection.
4179     * @return a new GreasedRegion that corresponds to the largest contiguous sub-region of "on" cells in this.
4180     */
4181    public GreasedRegion largestPart()
4182    {
4183        int fst = firstTight(), bestSize = 0, currentSize;
4184        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this), filled = new GreasedRegion(width, height),
4185                choice = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
4186        while (fst >= 0) {
4187            filled.empty().insert(fst).flood(remaining, width * height);
4188            if((currentSize = filled.size()) > bestSize)
4189            {
4190                bestSize = currentSize;
4191                choice.remake(filled);
4192            }
4193            remaining.andNot(filled);
4194            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4195        }
4196        return choice;
4197    }
4198
4199    /**
4200     * Finds the largest contiguous area of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and returns it; does not modify this
4201     * GreasedRegion. If there are multiple areas that are all equally large with no larger area, this returns the
4202     * region it checks first and still is largest (first determined by the same ordering {@link #nth(int)} takes).
4203     * This may return an empty GreasedRegion if there are no "on" cells, but it will never return null.
4204     * Here, contiguous means adjacent on any 8-way direction, and considers cells as part of a contiguous area even if
4205     * all connections but one, which can be orthogonal or diagonal, are blocked by "off" cells.
4206     * @return a new GreasedRegion that corresponds to the largest contiguous sub-region of "on" cells in this.
4207     */
4208    public GreasedRegion largestPart8way()
4209    {
4210        int fst = firstTight(), bestSize = 0, currentSize;
4211        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this), filled = new GreasedRegion(width, height),
4212                choice = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
4213        while (fst >= 0) {
4214            filled.empty().insert(fst).flood8way(remaining, width * height);
4215            if((currentSize = filled.size()) > bestSize)
4216            {
4217                bestSize = currentSize;
4218                choice.remake(filled);
4219            }
4220            remaining.andNot(filled);
4221            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4222        }
4223        return choice;
4224    }

4226    /**
4227     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so the only cells that will be "on" have a neighbor upwards when this is called.
4228     * Up is defined as negative y. Neighbors are "on" cells exactly one cell away. A cell can have a neighbor
4229     * without itself being on; this is useful when finding the "shadow" cast away from "on" cells in one direction.
4230     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
4231     */
4232    public GreasedRegion neighborUp()
4233    {
4234        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0)
4235            return this;
4236        for (int a = ySections - 1; a >= 0; a--) {
4237            if(a > 0) {
4238                for (int i = a; i < width * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4239                    data[i] = (data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63);
4240                }
4241            }
4242            else {
4243                for (int i = a; i < width * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4244                    data[i] = (data[i] << 1);
4245                }
4246            }
4247        }
4248        tallied = false;
4249        return this;
4250    }

4252    /**
4253     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so the only cells that will be "on" have a neighbor downwards when this is called.
4254     * Down is defined as positive y. Neighbors are "on" cells exactly one cell away. A cell can have a neighbor
4255     * without itself being on; this is useful when finding the "shadow" cast away from "on" cells in one direction.
4256     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
4257     */
4258    public GreasedRegion neighborDown()
4259    {
4260        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0)
4261            return this;
4262        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
4263            if(a < ySections - 1) {
4264                for (int i = a; i < width * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4265                    data[i] = (data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63);
4266                }
4267            }
4268            else {
4269                for (int i = a; i < width * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4270                    data[i] = (data[i] >>> 1);
4271                }
4272            }
4273        }
4274        tallied = false;
4275        return this;
4276    }

4278    /**
4279     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so the only cells that will be "on" have a neighbor to the left when this is called.
4280     * Left is defined as negative x. Neighbors are "on" cells exactly one cell away. A cell can have a neighbor
4281     * without itself being on; this is useful when finding the "shadow" cast away from "on" cells in one direction.
4282     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
4283     */
4284    public GreasedRegion neighborLeft()
4285    {
4286        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0)
4287            return this;
4288        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
4289            for (int i = ySections * (width - 1) + a; i >= ySections; i-= ySections) {
4290                data[i] = data[i - ySections];
4291            }
4292            data[a] = 0L;
4293        }
4294        tallied = false;
4295        return this;
4296    }

4300     * Right is defined as positive x. Neighbors are "on" cells exactly one cell away. A cell can have a neighbor
4301     * without itself being on; this is useful when finding the "shadow" cast away from "on" cells in one direction.

4304    public GreasedRegion neighborRight()

4307            return this;
4308        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
4309            for (int i = a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4310                data[i] = data[i + ySections];
4311            }
4312            data[(width-1)*ySections+a] = 0L;
4313        }
4314        tallied = false;
4315        return this;
4316    }

4321     * cell can have a neighbor without itself being on; this is useful when finding the "shadow" cast away from "on"

4333                }

4339                }

4433    public GreasedRegion removeIsolated()
4434    {
4435        int fst = firstTight();
4436        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this), filled = new GreasedRegion(this);
4437        while (fst >= 0) {
4438            filled.empty().insert(fst).flood(remaining, 8);
4439            if(filled.size() <= 4)
4440                andNot(filled);
4441            remaining.andNot(filled);
4442            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4443        }
4444        return this;
4445    }

4447    /**
4448     * Returns true if any cell is "on" in both this GreasedRegion and in other; returns false otherwise. For example,
4449     * if (1,1) is "on" in this and (1,1) is "on" in other, this would return true, regardless of other cells.
4450     * @param other another GreasedRegion; its size does not have to match this GreasedRegion's size
4451     * @return true if this shares any "on" cells with other
4452     */
4453    public boolean intersects(GreasedRegion other)
4454    {
4455        if(other == null)
4456            return false;
4457        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
4458            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
4459                if((data[x * ySections + y] & other.data[x * ySections + y]) != 0)
4460                    return true;
4461            }
4462        }
4463        return false;
4464    }

4466    public static OrderedSet<GreasedRegion> whichContain(int x, int y, GreasedRegion ... packed)
4467    {
4468        OrderedSet<GreasedRegion> found = new OrderedSet<>(packed.length);
4469        GreasedRegion tmp;
4470        for (int i = 0; i < packed.length; i++) {
4471            if((tmp = packed[i]) != null && tmp.contains(x, y))
4472                found.add(tmp);
4473        }
4474        return found;
4475    }
4476
4477    public static OrderedSet<GreasedRegion> whichContain(int x, int y, Collection<GreasedRegion> packed)
4478    {
4479        OrderedSet<GreasedRegion> found = new OrderedSet<>(packed.size());
4480        for (GreasedRegion tmp : packed) {
4481            if(tmp != null && tmp.contains(x, y))
4482                found.add(tmp);
4483        }
4484        return found;
4485    }

4488    public int size()
4489    {
4490        if(!tallied)
4491            tally();
4492        return ct;
4493    }
4494
4495    public Coord fit(double xFraction, double yFraction)
4496    {
4497        int tmp, xTotal = 0, yTotal = 0, xTarget, yTarget, bestX = -1;
4498        long t;
4499        int[] xCounts = new int[width];
4500        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4501            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4502                t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
4503                if (t != 0) {
4504                    tmp = Long.bitCount(t);
4505                    xCounts[x] += tmp;
4506                    xTotal += tmp;
4507                }
4508            }
4509        }
4510        xTarget = (int)(xTotal * xFraction);
4511        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4512            if((xTarget -= xCounts[x]) < 0)
4513            {
4514                bestX = x;
4515                yTotal = xCounts[x];
4516                break;
4517            }
4518        }
4519        if(bestX < 0)
4520        {
4521            return Coord.get(-1, -1);
4522        }
4523        yTarget = (int)(yTotal * yFraction);
4524
4525        for (int s = 0, y = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4526            t = data[bestX * ySections + s] | 0L;
4527            for (long cy = 1L; cy != 0L && y < height; y++, cy <<= 1) {
4528                if((t & (cy | 0L)) != 0 && --yTarget < 0)
4529                {
4530                    return Coord.get(bestX, y);
4531                }
4532            }
4533        }
4534
4535        return Coord.get(-1, -1);
4536    }
4537
4538    public int[][] fit(int[][] basis, int defaultValue)
4539    {
4540        int[][] next = ArrayTools.fill(defaultValue, width, height);
4541        if(basis == null || basis.length <= 0 || basis[0] == null || basis[0].length <= 0)
4542            return next;
4543        int tmp, xTotal = 0, yTotal = 0, xTarget, yTarget, bestX, oX = basis.length, oY = basis[0].length, ao;
4544        long t;
4545        int[] xCounts = new int[width];
4546        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4547            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4548                t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
4549                if (t != 0) {
4550                    tmp = Long.bitCount(t);
4551                    xCounts[x] += tmp;
4552                    xTotal += tmp;
4553                }
4554            }
4555        }
4556        if(xTotal <= 0)
4557            return next;
4558        for (int aX = 0; aX < oX; aX++) {
4559            CELL_WISE:
4560            for (int aY = 0; aY < oY; aY++) {
4561                if((ao = basis[aX][aY]) == defaultValue)
4562                    continue;
4563                xTarget = xTotal * aX / oX;
4564                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4565                    if((xTarget -= xCounts[x]) < 0)
4566                    {
4567                        bestX = x;
4568                        yTotal = xCounts[x];
4569                        yTarget = yTotal * aY / oY;
4570                        for (int s = 0, y = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4571                            t = data[bestX * ySections + s] | 0L;
4572                            for (long cy = 1L; cy != 0L && y < height; y++, cy <<= 1) {
4573                                if((t & (cy|0L)) != 0 && --yTarget < 0)
4574                                {
4575                                    next[bestX][y] = ao;
4576                                    continue CELL_WISE;
4577                                }
4578                            }
4579                        }
4580                        continue CELL_WISE;
4581                    }
4582                }
4583
4584            }
4585        }
4586
4587        return next;
4588    }
4589    
4590    /**
4591     * Don't use this in new code; prefer {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double)}, {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double)},
4592     * or {@link #separatedZCurve(double)}. This method has issues with being unable to fill the requested fraction, but
4593     * the others mentioned don't. See their documentation for what all these group of methods do.
4594     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0
4595     * @return a Coord array that may not have the full fraction used; you have been advised
4596     */
4597    public Coord[] separatedPortion(double fraction)
4598    {
4599        if(fraction < 0)
4600            return new Coord[0];
4601        if(fraction > 1)
4602            fraction = 1;
4603        int ct, tmp, xTotal = 0, yTotal = 0, xTarget, yTarget, bestX = -1;
4604        long t;
4605        int[] xCounts = new int[width];
4606        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4607            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4608                t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
4609                if (t != 0) {
4610                    tmp = Long.bitCount(t);
4611                    xCounts[x] += tmp;
4612                    xTotal += tmp;
4613                }
4614            }
4615        }
4616        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct = (int)(fraction * xTotal)];
4617        double[] vec = new double[2];
4618        sobol.skipTo(1337);
4619        EACH_SOBOL:
4620        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
4621        {
4622            sobol.fillVector(vec);
4623            xTarget = (int) (xTotal * vec[0]);
4624            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4625                if ((xTarget -= xCounts[x]) < 0) {
4626                    bestX = x;
4627                    yTotal = xCounts[x];
4628                    break;
4629                }
4630            }
4631            yTarget = (int) (yTotal * vec[1]);
4632
4633            for (int s = 0, y = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4634                t = data[bestX * ySections + s] | 0L;
4635                for (long cy = 1L; cy != 0L && y < height; y++, cy <<= 1) {
4636                    if ((t & (cy|0L)) != 0 && --yTarget < 0) {
4637                        vl[i] = Coord.get(bestX, y);
4638                        continue EACH_SOBOL;
4639                    }
4640                }
4641            }
4642        }
4643        return vl;
4644
4645    }
4646    /**
4647     * Don't use this in new code; prefer {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)} with a random long as the
4648     * last parameter. This method has issues with being unable to fill the requested fraction, but mixedRandomSeparated
4649     * does not. See its documentation for what this method is supposed to do.
4650     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0
4651     * @param rng an IRNG that will be used to get a random starting point in the Sobol sequence this uses internally
4652     * @return a Coord array that may not have the full fraction used; you have been advised
4653     */
4654    public Coord[] randomSeparated(double fraction, IRNG rng)
4655    {
4656        return randomSeparated(fraction, rng, -1);
4657    }
4658    /**
4659     * Don't use this in new code; prefer {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)} with a random long as the
4660     * last parameter. This method has issues with being unable to fill the requested fraction, but mixedRandomSeparated
4661     * does not. See its documentation for what this method is supposed to do.
4662     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0
4663     * @param rng an IRNG that will be used to get a random starting point in the Sobol sequence this uses internally
4664     * @param limit how many Coord values this should return, at most; typically this will return less
4665     * @return a Coord array that may not have the full fraction used; you have been advised
4666     */
4667    public Coord[] randomSeparated(double fraction, IRNG rng, int limit)
4668    {
4669        if(fraction < 0)
4670            return new Coord[0];
4671        if(fraction > 1)
4672            fraction = 1;
4673        int ct, tmp, xTotal = 0, yTotal = 0, xTarget, yTarget, bestX = -1;
4674        long t;
4675        int[] xCounts = new int[width];
4676        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4677            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4678                t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
4679                if (t != 0) {
4680                    tmp = Long.bitCount(t);
4681                    xCounts[x] += tmp;
4682                    xTotal += tmp;
4683                }
4684            }
4685        }
4686        ct = (int)(fraction * xTotal);
4687        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
4688            ct = limit;
4689        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
4690        double[] vec = new double[2];
4691        sobol.skipTo(rng.between(1000, 65000));
4692        EACH_SOBOL:
4693        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
4694        {
4695            sobol.fillVector(vec);
4696            xTarget = (int) (xTotal * vec[0]);
4697            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4698                if ((xTarget -= xCounts[x]) < 0) {
4699                    bestX = x;
4700                    yTotal = xCounts[x];
4701                    break;
4702                }
4703            }
4704            yTarget = (int) (yTotal * vec[1]);
4705
4706            for (int s = 0, y = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4707                t = data[bestX * ySections + s] | 0L;
4708                for (long cy = 1; cy != 0 && y < height; y++, cy <<= 1) {
4709                    if ((t & (cy|0L)) != 0 && --yTarget < 0) {
4710                        vl[i] = Coord.get(bestX, y);
4711                        continue EACH_SOBOL;
4712                    }
4713                }
4714            }
4715        }
4716        return vl;
4717
4718    }

4720    /**
4721     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a deterministic but random-seeming
4722     * scattering of chosen cells with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4723     * in this. This is pseudo-random with a fixed seed, but is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as
4724     * {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a
4725     * value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in
4726     * testing. Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to
4727     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.
4728     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4729     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
4730     */
4731    public Coord[] mixedRandomSeparated(double fraction)
4732    {
4733        return mixedRandomSeparated(fraction, -1, 1L);
4734    }

4736    /**
4737     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a deterministic but random-seeming
4738     * scattering of chosen cells with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4739     * in this. This is pseudo-random with a fixed seed, but is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as
4740     * {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a
4741     * value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in
4742     * testing. Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells
4743     * are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
4744     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4745     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
4746     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the pseudo-random cells
4747     */
4748    public Coord[] mixedRandomSeparated(double fraction, int limit)
4749    {
4750        return mixedRandomSeparated(fraction, limit, 1L);

4753    /**
4754     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a deterministic but random-seeming
4755     * scattering of chosen cells with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4756     * in this. This is pseudo-random with the given seed (which will be made into an odd number if it is not one
4757     * already), and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, and
4758     * probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but
4759     * a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in testing. Restricts the total size of the returned array to
4760     * a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the
4761     * size.
4762     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4763     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
4764     * @param seed a long seed to change the points; the most significant 21 bits (except the sign bit) and least significant bit are ignored
4765     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the pseudo-random cells
4766     */
4767    public Coord[] mixedRandomSeparated(double fraction, int limit, long seed) {
4768        if (fraction < 0)
4769            return new Coord[0];
4770        if (fraction > 1)
4771            fraction = 1;
4772        int tmp, ic;
4773        long t, w;
4774        seed |= 1L;
4775        final int total = size();
4776        int ct = (int) (total * fraction);
4777        if (limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
4778            ct = limit;
4779        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
4780        EACH_QUASI:
4781        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++) {
4782            tmp = (int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.altDetermine(seed, i + 1) * total);
4783
4784            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4785                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4786                    if ((ic = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
4787                        t = data[x * ySections + s]|0L;
4788                        for (--ic; t != 0; ic--) {
4789                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
4790                            if (ic == tmp) {
4791                                vl[i] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.bitCount(w - 1));
4792                                continue EACH_QUASI;
4793                            }
4794                            t ^= w;
4795                        }
4796                    }
4797                }
4798            }
4799        }
4800        return vl;
4801    }

4808     * in this. This is pseudo-random with a fixed seed, and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as
4809     * {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a
4810     * value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in
4811     * testing. Does not restrict the count of "on" cells after this returns other than by only using up to
4812     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.

4814     * @return this for chaining

4816    public GreasedRegion mixedRandomRegion(double fraction) {

4819    /**
4820     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a deterministic but random-seeming subset of its previous contents,
4821     * choosing cells so that the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4822     * in this. This is pseudo-random with a fixed seed, and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as
4823     * {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a
4824     * value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in
4825     * testing. Restricts the total count of "on" cells after this returns to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0
4826     * if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the count.
4827     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4828     * @param limit the maximum count of "on" cells to keep
4829     * @return this for chaining
4830     */
4831    public GreasedRegion mixedRandomRegion(double fraction, int limit) {
4832        return mixedRandomRegion(fraction, limit, 1L);

4834    /**
4835     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a deterministic but random-seeming subset of its previous contents,
4836     * choosing cells so that the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4837     * in this. This is pseudo-random with the given seed (which will be made into an odd number if it is not one
4838     * already), and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, and
4839     * probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but
4840     * a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in testing. Restricts the total count of "on" cells after
4841     * this returns to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will
4842     * not restrict the count.
4843     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4844     * @param limit the maximum count of "on" cells to keep
4845     * @return this for chaining
4846     */
4847    public GreasedRegion mixedRandomRegion(double fraction, int limit, long seed) {
4848        int idx, run = 0;
4849        final int total = size();
4850        if (total <= limit)
4851            return this;
4852        if (total <= 0)
4853            return empty();
4854        if (limit < 0)
4855            limit = (int) (fraction * ct);
4856        if(limit <= 0)
4857            return empty();
4858        seed |= 1L;
4859        int[] order = new int[limit];
4860        for (int i = 0, m = 1; i < limit; i++, m++) {
4861            idx = (int)(VanDerCorputQRNG.altDetermine(seed, m) * total);
4862            BIG:
4863            while (true) {
4864                for (int j = 0; j < i; j++) {
4865                    if (order[j] == idx) {
4866                        idx = (int)(VanDerCorputQRNG.altDetermine(seed, ++m) * total);
4867                        continue BIG;
4868                    }
4869                }
4870                break;
4871            }
4872            order[i] = idx;
4873        }
4874        idx = 0;
4875        Arrays.sort(order);
4876        long t, w;
4877        ALL:
4878        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4879            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4880                if ((t = data[x * ySections + s]|0L) != 0L) {
4881                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
4882                    while (w != 0) {
4883                        if (run++ == order[idx]) {
4884                            if (++idx >= limit) {
4885                                data[x * ySections + s] &= (w<<1)-1;
4886                                for (int rx = x+1; rx < width; rx++) {
4887                                    data[rx * ySections + s] = 0;
4888                                }
4889                                for (int rs = s+1; rs < ySections; rs++) {
4890                                    for (int rx = 0; rx < width; rx++) {
4891                                        data[rx * ySections + rs] = 0;
4892                                    }
4893                                }
4894                                break ALL;
4895                            }
4896                        } else {
4897                            data[x * ySections + s] ^= w;
4898                        }
4899                        t ^= w;
4900                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
4901                    }
4902                }
4903            }
4904        }
4905        tallied = false;
4906        return this;
4907    }

4909    /**
4910     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
4911     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
4912     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
4913     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however.
4914     * Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to {@code fraction * size()} cells.
4915     * <br>
4916     * You can choose between {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double)}, {@link #separatedZCurve(double)}, and this method,
4917     * where all are quasi-random, mixedRandom is probably fastest, ZCurve may have better 2-dimensional gaps between
4918     * cells, and this method is somewhere in the middle.
4919     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4920     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
4921     */
4922    public Coord[] quasiRandomSeparated(double fraction)
4923    {
4924        return quasiRandomSeparated(fraction, -1);
4925    }

4927    /**
4928     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
4929     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
4930     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
4931     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however.
4932     * Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on").
4933     * If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
4934     * <br>
4935     * You can choose between {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int)}, {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, and
4936     * this method, where all are quasi-random, mixedRandom is probably fastest, ZCurve may have better 2-dimensional
4937     * gaps between cells, and this method is somewhere in the middle.
4938     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4939     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
4940     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
4941     */
4942    public Coord[] quasiRandomSeparated(double fraction, int limit)
4943    {
4944        if(fraction < 0)
4945            return new Coord[0];
4946        if(fraction > 1)
4947            fraction = 1;
4948        int ct = 0, tmp, total, ic;
4949        long t, w;
4950        int[] counts = new int[width * ySections];
4951        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
4952            tmp = Long.bitCount(data[i]);
4953            counts[i] = tmp == 0 ? -1 : (ct += tmp);
4954        }
4955        total = ct;
4956        ct *= fraction;// (int)(fraction * ct);
4957        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
4958            ct = limit;
4959        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
4960        EACH_QUASI:
4961        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
4962        {
4963            tmp = (int)(VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(i ^ i >>> 1) * total);
4964            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4965                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4966                    if ((ic = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
4967                        t = data[x * ySections + s];
4968                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
4969                        for (--ic; w != 0; ic--) {
4970                            if (ic == tmp) {
4971                                vl[i] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
4972                                continue EACH_QUASI;
4973                            }
4974                            t ^= w;
4975                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
4976                        }
4977                    }
4978                }
4979            }
4980            vl[i] = atFraction(tmp);
4981        }
4982        return vl;
4983    }

4990     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you

4992     * Does not restrict the count of "on" cells after this returns other than by only using up to
4993     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.

4995     * You can choose between {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double)}, {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double)}, and this
4996     * method, where all are quasi-random, mixedRandom is probably fastest, ZCurve may have better 2-dimensional gaps
4997     * between cells, and this method is somewhere in the middle.

5004    /**
5005     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5006     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5007     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5008     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however.
5009     * Restricts the total count of "on" cells after this returns to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no
5010     * cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the count.
5011     * <br>
5012     * You can choose between {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int)}, {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and
5013     * this method, where all are quasi-random, mixedRandom is probably fastest, ZCurve may have better 2-dimensional
5014     * gaps between cells, and this method is somewhere in the middle.
5015     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5016     * @param limit the maximum count of "on" cells to keep
5017     * @return this for chaining
5018     */
5019    public GreasedRegion quasiRandomRegion(double fraction, int limit) {
5020        int ct = size(), idx, run = 0;
5021        if (ct <= limit)
5022            return this;
5023        if (ct <= 0)
5024            return empty();
5025        if (limit < 0)
5026            limit = (int) (fraction * ct);
5027        if(limit <= 0)
5028            return empty();
5029        int[] order = new int[limit];
5030        for (int i = 0, m = 1; i < limit; i++, m++) {
5031            idx = (int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(m) * ct);
5032            BIG:
5033            while (true) {
5034                for (int j = 0; j < i; j++) {
5035                    if (order[j] == idx) {
5036                        idx = (int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(++m) * ct);
5037                        continue BIG;
5038                    }
5039                }
5040                break;
5041            }
5042            order[i] = idx;
5043        }
5044        idx = 0;
5045        Arrays.sort(order);
5046        long t, w;
5047        ALL:
5048        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5049            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5050                if ((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0) {
5051                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5052                    while (w != 0) {
5053                        if (run++ == order[idx]) {
5054                            if (++idx >= limit) {
5055                                data[x * ySections + s] &= (w<<1)-1;
5056                                for (int rx = x+1; rx < width; rx++) {
5057                                    data[rx * ySections + s] = 0;
5058                                }
5059                                for (int rs = s+1; rs < ySections; rs++) {
5060                                    for (int rx = 0; rx < width; rx++) {
5061                                        data[rx * ySections + rs] = 0;
5062                                    }
5063                                }
5064                                break ALL;
5065                            }
5066                        } else {
5067                            data[x * ySections + s] ^= w;
5068                        }
5069                        t ^= w;
5070                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5071                    }
5072                }
5073            }
5074        }
5075        tallied = false;
5076        return this;
5077    }

5079    /**
5080     * Like {@link #retract()}, this removes the "on" cells that are 4-way-adjacent to any "off" cell, but unlike that
5081     * method it keeps a fraction of those surface cells, quasi-randomly selecting them. This can be thought of as
5082     * running {@link #surface()} on a copy of this GreasedRegion, running {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double)} on that
5083     * surface with the given fractionKept, taking the original GreasedRegion and removing its whole surface with
5084     * {@link #retract()}, then inserting the quasi-randomly-removed surface into this GreasedRegion to replace its
5085     * surface with a randomly "damaged" one.
5086     * @param fractionKept the fraction between 0.0 and 1.0 of how many cells on the outer surface of this to keep "on"
5087     * @return this for chaining
5088     */
5089    public GreasedRegion fray(double fractionKept)
5090    {
5091        GreasedRegion cpy = new GreasedRegion(this).retract();
5092        return xor(cpy).quasiRandomRegion(1.0 - fractionKept).or(cpy);
5093    }

5106    /**
5107     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that the
5108     * distance between any two "on" cells is at least {@code minimumDistance}, with at least one cell as "on" if any
5109     * were "on" in this originally.
5110     * Restricts the total count of "on" cells after this returns to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no
5111     * cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the count.
5112     * @param rng used to generate random positions
5113     * @param minimumDistance the minimum distance between "on" cells in the result
5114     * @param limit the maximum count of "on" cells to keep
5115     * @return this for chaining
5116     */
5117    public GreasedRegion randomScatter(IRNG rng, int minimumDistance, int limit) {
5118        int tmp, total = 0, ct;
5119        tally();
5120        if(this.ct == 0)
5121            return this;
5122        if(limit == 0)
5123            return empty();
5124        else if(limit < 0)
5125            limit = width * height;
5126        long t, w;
5127        long[] data2 = new long[data.length];
5128        MAIN_LOOP:
5129        while (total < limit) { 
5130            if(!tallied) 
5131                tally();
5132            tmp = rng.nextInt(this.ct);
5133
5134            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5135                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5136                    if ((ct = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
5137                        t = data[x * ySections + s];
5138                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5139                        for (--ct; w != 0; ct--) {
5140                            if (ct == tmp) {
5141                                removeRectangle(x - minimumDistance,
5142                                        ((s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w)) - minimumDistance,
5143                                        minimumDistance << 1 | 1, minimumDistance << 1 | 1);
5144                                data2[x * ySections + s] |= w;
5145                                ++total;
5146                                continue MAIN_LOOP;
5147                            }
5148                            t ^= w;
5149                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5150                        }
5151                    }
5152                }
5153            }
5154            break;
5155        }
5156        data = data2;
5157        tallied = false;
5158        return this;
5159    }
5160
5161    public double rateDensity()
5162    {
5163        double sz = height * width;
5164        if(sz == 0)
5165            return 0;
5166        double onAmount = sz - size(), retractedOn = sz - copy().retract().size();
5167        return (onAmount + retractedOn) / (sz * 2.0);
5168    }
5169    public double rateRegularity()
5170    {
5171        GreasedRegion me2 = copy().surface8way();
5172        double irregularCount = me2.size();
5173        if(irregularCount == 0)
5174            return 0;
5175        return me2.remake(this).surface().size() / irregularCount;
5176    }

5178    private static int median(int[] working, int start, int amount)
5179    {
5180        Arrays.sort(working, start, start + amount);
5181        if ((amount & 1) == 0) {
5182            return working[start + (amount >> 1) - 1] + working[start + (amount >> 1)] >>> 1;
5183        } else {
5184            return working[start + (amount >> 1)];
5185        }
5186    }
5187
5188    /**
5189     * Calculates a perceptual hash for this GreasedRegion using a method that is only precise for some sizes of
5190     * GreasedRegion; it writes a result to into, and uses working as a temporary buffer. The lengths of into and
5191     * working should be related; if into is length 1, then working should be length 64, and though the hash won't be
5192     * very detailed, it will work well for images with width and height that are multiples of 8; if into is length 4,
5193     * then working should be length 256, and this will work with more detail on images that have width and height that
5194     * are multiples of 16. If working is null or is too small, then this won't reuse it and will allocate an
5195     * appropriately-sized array for internal use.
5196     * <br>
5197     * Ported from https://github.com/commonsmachinery/blockhash/blob/master/blockhash.c , which is MIT-licensed.
5198     * @param into should be a long array of length 1 or 4; the contents don't matter and this will be where output is written to
5199     * @param working should be an int array of length 64 (if into has length 1) or 256 (if into has length 4); may be null if you like garbage collection
5200     */
5201    public void perceptualHashQuick(long[] into, int[] working)
5202    {
5203        final int bits = 8 << (Integer.numberOfTrailingZeros(Integer.highestOneBit(into.length)) >> 1);
5204        if(working == null || working.length < bits * bits)
5205            working = new int[bits * bits];
5206        final int blockWidth = width / bits, blockHeight = height / bits, blockWidthSections = blockWidth * ySections;
5207        if(blockHeight == 1)
5208        {
5209            for (int y = 0; y < bits; y++) {
5210                for (int x = 0; x < bits; x++) {
5211                    int value = 0;
5212                    for (int ix = 0; ix < blockWidthSections; ix += ySections) {
5213                        value += (data[x * blockWidthSections + ix + (y >> 6)] >>> (y & 63) & 1L);
5214                    }
5215                    working[x * bits + y] = value;
5216                }
5217            }
5218        }
5219        else if(blockHeight < 64 && Integer.bitCount(blockHeight) == 1) {
5220            final long yBlockMask = ~(-1L << blockHeight);
5221            final int divisorMask = (64 / blockHeight) - 1;
5222            long currentMask;
5223            int blockY = 0;
5224            for (int y = 0; y < bits; y++, blockY += blockHeight) {
5225                currentMask = yBlockMask << ((y & divisorMask) << blockHeight);
5226                for (int x = 0; x < bits; x++) {
5227                    int value = 0;
5228                    for (int ix = 0; ix < blockWidthSections; ix += ySections) {
5229                        value += Long.bitCount(data[x * blockWidthSections + ix + (blockY >> 6)] & currentMask);
5230                    }
5231                    working[x * bits + y] = value;
5232                }
5233            }
5234        }
5235        final int cellsPerBlock = blockWidth * blockHeight, numBlocks = bits * bits,
5236                halfCellCount = cellsPerBlock >>> 1;
5237        int bandSize = numBlocks >>> 2;
5238        int m, v;
5239        int currentInto = 0;
5240        long currentIntoPos = 1L;
5241        for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
5242            m = median(working, i * bandSize, bandSize);
5243            for (int j = i * bandSize; j < (i + 1) * bandSize; j++) {
5244                v = working[j];
5245                if(v > m || (v - m == 0 && m > halfCellCount)) into[currentInto] |= currentIntoPos;
5246                if((currentIntoPos <<= 1) == 0)
5247                {
5248                    ++currentInto;
5249                    currentIntoPos = 1L;
5250                }
5251            }
5252        }
5253    }

5257    // It also produced very close-together points, unfortunately.
5258    public static double quasiRandomX(int idx)
5259    {
5260        return atVDCSequence(26 + idx * 5);

5263    {
5264        return atVDCSequence(19 + idx * 3);

5267    private static double atVDCSequence(int idx)
5268    {
5269        int leading = Integer.numberOfLeadingZeros(idx);
5270        return (Integer.reverse(idx) >>> leading) / (1.0 * (1 << (32 - leading)));
5271    }
5272    */
5273    public Coord[] asCoords()
5274    {
5275        return asCoords(new Coord[size()]);
5276
5277    }
5278    public Coord[] asCoords(Coord[] points)
5279    {
5280        if(points == null)
5281            points = new Coord[size()];
5282        int idx = 0, len = points.length;
5283        long t, w;
5284        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5285            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5286                if((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0)
5287                {
5288                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5289                    while (w != 0) {
5290                        if(idx >= len) return points;
5291                        points[idx++] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5292                        t ^= w;
5293                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5294                    }
5295                }
5296            }
5297        }
5298        return points;
5299    }
5300    public int[] asEncoded()
5301    {
5302        int ct = size(), idx = 0;
5303        int[] points = new int[ct];
5304        long t, w;
5305        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5306            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5307                if((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0)
5308                {
5309                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5310                    while (w != 0) {
5311                        points[idx++] = Coord.pureEncode(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5312                        t ^= w;
5313                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5314                    }
5315                }
5316            }
5317        }
5318        return points;
5319    }

5390    public Coord nth(final int index)
5391    {
5392        if(index < 0)
5393            return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5394        int ct = size(), tmp;
5395        if(index >= ct)
5396            return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5397        long t, w;
5398        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5399            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5400                if ((ct = counts[x * ySections + s]) > index) {
5401                    t = data[x * ySections + s];
5402                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5403                    for (--ct; w != 0; ct--) {
5404                        if (ct == index)
5405                            return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5406                        t ^= w;
5407                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5408                    }
5409                }
5410            }
5411        }
5412        return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5413    }

5420        long t, w;

5422            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5423                if ((ct = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
5424                    t = data[x * ySections + s];

5428                            return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5429                        t ^= w;
5430                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5431                    }
5432                }
5433            }
5434        }

5462    /**
5463     * Gets a single random Coord from the "on" positions in this GreasedRegion, or the Coord (-1,-1) if this is empty.
5464     * Uses the given IRNG to generate one random int, which is used as an index. The technique this uses to iterate
5465     * over bits can be credited to Erling Ellingsen and Daniel Lemire, found
5466     * <a href="https://lemire.me/blog/2013/12/23/even-faster-bitmap-decoding/">here</a>, and seems to be a little
5467     * faster than the previous method. The fastest way to get a random Coord from a GreasedRegion is to avoid iterating
5468     * over the bits at all, so if your region data doesn't change you should get it as a Coord array with
5469     * {@link #asCoords()} and call {@link IRNG#getRandomElement(Object[])} with that array as the parameter. If you
5470     * take the asCoords() call out of consideration, getting random elements out of an array (especially a large one)
5471     * can be hundreds of times faster.
5472     * @param rng an IRNG such as an {@link RNG} or {@link GWTRNG}
5473     * @return a single randomly-chosen Coord from the "on" positions in this GreasedRegion, or (-1,-1) if empty
5474     */
5475    public Coord singleRandom(IRNG rng)
5476    {
5477        int ct = size(), tmp = rng.nextInt(ct);
5478        long t, w;
5479        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5480            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5481                if ((ct = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
5482                    t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
5483                    for (--ct; t != 0; ct--) {
5484                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5485                        if (ct == tmp)
5486                            return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.bitCount(w-1));
5487                        t ^= w;
5488                    }
5489                }
5490            }
5491        }
5492        return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5493    }
5494
5495    public int singleRandomTight(IRNG rng)
5496    {
5497        int ct = size(), tmp = rng.nextInt(ct);
5498        long t, w;
5499        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5500            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5501                if ((ct = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
5502                    t = data[x * ySections + s];
5503                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5504                    for (--ct; w != 0; ct--) {
5505                        if (ct == tmp)
5506                            return ((s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w)) * width + x;
5507                        t ^= w;
5508                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5509                    }
5510                }
5511            }
5512        }
5513
5514        return -1;
5515    }
