5517    /**
5518     * Narrow-purpose; takes an x and a y value, each between 0 and 65535 inclusive, and interleaves their bits so the
5519     * least significant bit and every other bit after it are filled with the bits of x, while the
5520     * second-least-significant bit and every other bit after that are filled with the bits of y. Essentially, this
5521     * takes two numbers with bits labeled like {@code a b c} for x and {@code R S T} for y and makes a number with
5522     * those bits arranged like {@code R a S b T c}.
5523     * @param x an int between 0 and 65535, inclusive
5524     * @param y an int between 0 and 65535, inclusive
5525     * @return an int that interleaves x and y, with x in the least significant bit position
5526     */
5527    public static int interleaveBits(int x, int y)
5528    {
5529        x |= y << 16;
5530        x =    ((x & 0x0000ff00) << 8) | ((x >>> 8) & 0x0000ff00) | (x & 0xff0000ff);
5531        x =    ((x & 0x00f000f0) << 4) | ((x >>> 4) & 0x00f000f0) | (x & 0xf00ff00f);
5532        x =    ((x & 0x0c0c0c0c) << 2) | ((x >>> 2) & 0x0c0c0c0c) | (x & 0xc3c3c3c3);
5533        return ((x & 0x22222222) << 1) | ((x >>> 1) & 0x22222222) | (x & 0x99999999);
5534    }
5535
5536    /**
5537     * Narrow-purpose; takes an int that represents a distance down the Z-order curve and moves its bits around so that
5538     * its x component is stored in the bottom 16 bits (use {@code (n & 0xffff)} to obtain) and its y component is
5539     * stored in the upper 16 bits (use {@code (n >>> 16)} to obtain). This may be useful for ordering traversals of all
5540     * points in a GreasedRegion less predictably.
5541     * @param n an int that has already been interleaved, though this can really be any int
5542     * @return an int with x in its lower bits ({@code x = n & 0xffff;}) and y in its upper bits ({@code y = n >>> 16;})
5543     */
5544    public static int disperseBits(int n)
5545    {
5546        n =    ((n & 0x22222222) << 1) | ((n >>> 1) & 0x22222222) | (n & 0x99999999);
5547        n =    ((n & 0x0c0c0c0c) << 2) | ((n >>> 2) & 0x0c0c0c0c) | (n & 0xc3c3c3c3);
5548        n =    ((n & 0x00f000f0) << 4) | ((n >>> 4) & 0x00f000f0) | (n & 0xf00ff00f);
5549        return ((n & 0x0000ff00) << 8) | ((n >>> 8) & 0x0000ff00) | (n & 0xff0000ff);
5550    }
5551    private static int nextPowerOfTwo(int n)
5552    {
5553        final int highest = Integer.highestOneBit(n);
5554        return  (highest == NumberTools.lowestOneBit(n)) ? highest : highest << 1;
5555    }
5556
5557    /**
5558     * Like {@link #nth(int)}, this gets the Coord at a given index along a path through the GreasedRegion, but unlike
5559     * nth(), this traverses the path in a zig-zag pattern called the Z-Order Curve. This method is often not very fast
5560     * compared to nth(), but this different path can help if iteration needs to seem less regular while still covering
5561     * all "on" cells in the GresedRegion eventually.
5562     * @param index the distance along the Z-order curve to travel, only counting "on" cells in this GreasedRegion.
5563     * @return the Coord at the given distance, or the Coord with x and y both -1 if index is too high or low
5564     */
5565    public Coord nthZCurve(final int index)
5566    {
5567        int ct = -1, x, y, s, d, max = nextPowerOfTwo(width) * nextPowerOfTwo(height);
5568        long t, w;
5569        for (int o = 0; o < max; o++) {
5570            d = disperseBits(o);
5571            x = d & 0xffff;
5572            y = d >>> 16;
5573            if(x >= width && y >= height)
5574                break;
5575            if(x >= width)
5576                continue;
5577            if(y >= height)
5578                continue;
5579            s = d >>> 22;
5580            t = data[x * ySections + s];
5581            if((ct += (t >>> (y & 63) & 1L)) == index)
5582                return Coord.get(x, y);
5583        }
5584        return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5585    }
5586    /**
5587     * Like {@link #nth(int)}, this finds a given index along a path through the GreasedRegion, but unlike nth(), this
5588     * traverses the path in a zig-zag pattern called the Z-Order Curve, and unlike {@link #nthZCurve(int)}, this does
5589     * not return a Coord and instead produces a "tight"-encoded int. This method is often not very fast compared to
5590     * nth(), but this different path can help if iteration needs to seem less regular while still covering all "on"
5591     * cells in the GreasedRegion eventually, and the tight encoding may be handy if you need to use ints.
5592     * @param index the distance along the Z-order curve to travel, only counting "on" cells in this GreasedRegion.
5593     * @return the "tight" encoded point at the given distance, or -1 if index is too high or low
5594     */
5595
5596    public int nthZCurveTight(final int index)
5597    {
5598        int ct = -1, x, y, s, d, max = nextPowerOfTwo(width) * nextPowerOfTwo(height);
5599        long t;
5600        for (int o = 0; o < max; o++) {
5601            d = disperseBits(o);
5602            x = d & 0xffff;
5603            y = d >>> 16;
5604            if(x >= width && y >= height)
5605                break;
5606            if(x >= width)
5607                continue;
5608            if(y >= height)
5609                continue;
5610            s = d >>> 22;
5611            t = data[x * ySections + s];
5612            if((ct += (t >>> (y & 63) & 1L)) == index)
5613                return y * width + x;
5614        }
5615        return -1;
5616    }
5617
5618    /**
5619     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5620     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5621     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5622     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however. Contrast with
5623     * {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int)}, which tends to overlap more frequently. This method seems to work
5624     * well because it chooses quasi-random points by their index in the Z-Order Curve as opposed to the simpler
5625     * approach mixedRandomSeparated uses to traverse points (which just runs through the "on" cells a column at a time,
5626     * not caring if two points are in adjacent cells as long as they are in different columns). Testing with a dungeon
5627     * layout of mostly-on cells, this method has no overlap with a fraction of 0.4, while mixedRandomSeparated has
5628     * overlap as early as 0.15 for fraction, and it only gets worse at higher values. A change to the algorithm used by
5629     * {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double)} has it overlapping at the same rate as this method, though it should be
5630     * much faster. This method can be especially slow, since each Z-Order traversal may need to try many cells that are
5631     * outside the GreasedRegion but are on the Z-Order Curve.
5632     * Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5633     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5634     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5635     */
5636    public Coord[] separatedZCurve(double fraction)
5637    {
5638        return separatedZCurve(fraction, -1);
5639    }
5640
5641    /**
5642     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5643     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5644     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5645     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however. Contrast with
5646     * {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int)}, which tends to overlap more frequently. This method seems to work
5647     * well because it chooses quasi-random points by their index in the Z-Order Curve as opposed to the simpler
5648     * approach mixedRandomSeparated uses to traverse points (which just runs through the "on" cells a column at a time,
5649     * not caring if two points are in adjacent cells as long as they are in different columns). Testing with a dungeon
5650     * layout of mostly-on cells, this method has no overlap with a fraction of 0.4, while mixedRandomSeparated has
5651     * overlap as early as 0.15 for fraction, and it only gets worse at higher values. A change to the algorithm used by
5652     * {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double, int)} has it overlapping at the same rate as this method, though it should
5653     * be much faster. This method can be especially slow, since each Z-Order traversal may need to try many cells that
5654     * are outside the GreasedRegion but are on the Z-Order Curve.
5655     * Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on").
5656     * If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
5657     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5658     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
5659     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5660     */
5661    public Coord[] separatedZCurve(double fraction, int limit)
5662    {
5663        if(fraction < 0)
5664            return new Coord[0];
5665        if(fraction > 1)
5666            fraction = 1;
5667        int ct = size(), total;
5668        total = ct;
5669        ct *= fraction;
5670        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
5671            ct = limit;
5672        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
5673        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
5674        {
5675            vl[i] = nthZCurve((int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(i ^ i >>> 1) * total));
5676        }
5677        return vl;
5678    }
5679    /**
5680     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5681     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5682     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5683     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however. Contrast with
5684     * {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double)}, which tends to overlap more frequently. This method seems to work
5685     * well because it chooses quasi-random points by their index in the Z-Order Curve as opposed to the simpler
5686     * approach mixedRandomRegion uses to traverse points (which just runs through the "on" cells a column at a time,
5687     * not caring if two points are in adjacent cells as long as they are in different columns). Testing with a dungeon
5688     * layout of mostly-on cells, this method has no overlap with a fraction of 0.4, while mixedRandomRegion has
5689     * overlap as early as 0.15 for fraction, and it only gets worse at higher values. A change to the algorithm used by
5690     * {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double)} has it overlapping at the same rate as this method, though it should be much
5691     * faster. This method can be especially slow, since each Z-Order traversal may need to try many cells that are
5692     * outside the GreasedRegion but are on the Z-Order Curve.
5693     * Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5694     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5695     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
5696     */
5697    public GreasedRegion separatedRegionZCurve(double fraction)
5698    {
5699        return separatedRegionZCurve(fraction, -1);
5700    }

5702    /**
5703     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5704     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5705     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5706     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however. Contrast with
5707     * {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int)}, which tends to overlap more frequently. This method seems to work
5708     * well because it chooses quasi-random points by their index in the Z-Order Curve as opposed to the simpler
5709     * approach mixedRandomRegion uses to traverse points (which just runs through the "on" cells a column at a time,
5710     * not caring if two points are in adjacent cells as long as they are in different columns). Testing with a dungeon
5711     * layout of mostly-on cells, this method has no overlap with a fraction of 0.4, while mixedRandomRegion has
5712     * overlap as early as 0.15 for fraction, and it only gets worse at higher values. A change to the algorithm used by
5713     * {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double, int)} has it overlapping at the same rate as this method, though it should be
5714     * much faster. This method can be especially slow, since each Z-Order traversal may need to try many cells that
5715     * are outside the GreasedRegion but are on the Z-Order Curve.
5716     * Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on").
5717     * If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
5718     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5719     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
5720     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
5721     */
5722    public GreasedRegion separatedRegionZCurve(double fraction, int limit)
5723    {
5724        if(fraction <= 0)
5725            return empty();
5726        if(fraction >= 1)
5727            return this;
5728        int ct = size(), total;
5729        if(limit >= ct)
5730            return this;
5731        total = ct;
5732        ct *= fraction;
5733        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
5734            ct = limit;
5735        int[] vl = new int[ct];
5736        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
5737        {
5738            vl[i] = nthZCurveTight((int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(i ^ i >>> 1) * total));
5739        }
5740        return empty().insertSeveral(vl);
5741    }

5743    /**
5744     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5745     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5746     * random instead of pseudo-random because it uses blue noise to sharply limit the likelihood of nearby points being
5747     * chosen when fraction is small. If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to
5748     * have nearby cells, however. Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to
5749     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5750     * <br>
5751     * Also take a look at {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double, int)},
5752     * {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)}, and {@link #separatedRegionBlue(double, int)}. Internally, this
5753     * is a thin wrapper around {@link #separatedRegionBlue(double, int)}, and won't be more efficient than that method.
5754     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5755     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5756     */
5757    public Coord[] separatedBlue(double fraction)
5758    {
5759        return separatedBlue(fraction, -1);
5760    }
5761
5762    /**
5763     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5764     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5765     * random instead of pseudo-random because it uses blue noise to sharply limit the likelihood of nearby points being
5766     * chosen when fraction is small. If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to
5767     * have nearby cells, however. Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum
5768     * is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
5769     * <br>
5770     * Also take a look at {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double, int)},
5771     * {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)}, and {@link #separatedRegionBlue(double, int)}. Internally, this
5772     * is a thin wrapper around {@link #separatedRegionBlue(double, int)}, and won't be more efficient than that method.
5773     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5774     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return; may return less
5775     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5776     */
5777    public Coord[] separatedBlue(double fraction, int limit)
5778    {
5779        if(fraction <= 0)
5780            return new Coord[0];
5781        if(fraction > 0xFFp-8)
5782            fraction = 0xFFp-8;
5783        int ct = size();
5784        if(limit >= ct)
5785            return asCoords();
5786        return copy().separatedRegionBlue(fraction, limit).asCoords();
5787    }
5788    /**
5789     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5790     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5791     * random instead of pseudo-random because it uses blue noise to sharply limit the likelihood of nearby points being
5792     * chosen when fraction is small. If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to
5793     * have nearby cells, however. Does not restrict the size of the returned GreasedRegion other than only using up to
5794     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5795     * <br>
5796     * Also take a look at {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double, int)},
5797     * {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int, long)}, and {@link #separatedBlue(double, int)}.
5798     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5799     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
5800     */
5801    public GreasedRegion separatedRegionBlue(double fraction)

5806    /**
5807     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5808     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5809     * random instead of pseudo-random because it uses blue noise to sharply limit the likelihood of nearby points being
5810     * chosen when fraction is small. If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to
5811     * have nearby cells, however. Restricts the total size of the returned GreasedRegion to a maximum of {@code limit}
5812     * (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
5813     * <br>
5814     * Also take a look at {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double, int)},
5815     * {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int, long)}, and {@link #separatedBlue(double, int)}.
5816     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to quasi-randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5817     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return; may return less
5818     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
5819     */
5820    public GreasedRegion separatedRegionBlue(double fraction, int limit)
5821    {
5822        if(fraction <= 0)
5823            return empty();
5824        if(fraction > 0xFFp-8)
5825            fraction = 0xFFp-8;
5826        int ct = size();
5827        if(limit >= ct)
5828            return this;
5829        ct *= fraction;
5830        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
5831            ct = limit;
5832        for (int i = 255; i >= 0; i--) {
5833            if(ct >= andWrapping64(BlueNoise.LEVELS[i]).size())
5834                return this;
5835        }
5836        return this;
5837    }
5838
5839    public Coord[] randomPortion(IRNG rng, int size)
5840    {
5841        int ct = size(), idx = 0, run = 0;
5842        if(ct <= 0 || size <= 0)
5843            return new Coord[0];
5844        if(ct <= size)
5845            return asCoords();
5846        Coord[] points = new Coord[size];
5847        int[] order = rng.randomOrdering(ct);
5848        Arrays.sort(order, 0, size);
5849        long t, w;
5850        ALL:
5851        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5852            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5853                if((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0)
5854                {
5855                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5856                    while (w != 0) {
5857                        if (run++ == order[idx]) {
5858                            points[idx++] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5859                            if (idx >= size) break ALL;
5860                        }
5861                        t ^= w;
5862                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5863                    }
5864                }
5865            }
5866        }
5867        return points;
5868    }
5869
5870    public GreasedRegion randomRegion(IRNG rng, int size)
5871    {
5872        int ct = size(), idx = 0, run = 0;
5873        if(ct <= 0 || size <= 0)
5874            return empty();
5875        if(ct <= size)
5876            return this;
5877        int[] order = rng.randomOrdering(ct);
5878        Arrays.sort(order, 0, size);
5879        long t, w;
5880        ALL:
5881        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5882            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5883                if((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0)
5884                {
5885                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5886                    while (w != 0) {
5887                        if (run++ == order[idx]) {
5888                            if(++idx >= size) break ALL;
5889                        }
5890                        else
5891                        {
5892                            data[x * ySections + s] &= ~(1L << Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5893                        }
5894                        t ^= w;
5895                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5896                    }
5897                }
5898            }
5899        }
5900        tallied = false;
5901        return this;
5902    }
5903
5904    @Override
5905    public boolean contains(int x, int y)
5906    {
5907        return x >= 0 && y >= 0 && x < width && y < height && ySections > 0 &&
5908                ((data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0);
5909    }
5910
5911
5912    /**
5913     * @return Whether this zone is empty.
5914     */
5915    @Override
5916    public boolean isEmpty() {
5917        if(tallied) return ct > 0;
5918        for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
5919            if(data[i] != 0L) return false;
5920        }
5921        return true;
5922    }
5923
5924    /**
5925     * Generates a 2D int array from an array or vararg of GreasedRegions, starting at all 0 and adding 1 to the int at
5926     * a position once for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on." This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
5927     * this method, it can produce any number between 0 and 8 in a cell; if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
5928     * produce any number between 0 and 16 in a cell.
5929     * @param regions an array or vararg of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
5930     * @return a 2D int array with the same width and height as the regions, where an int cell equals the number of given GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
5931     */
5932    public static int[][] sum(GreasedRegion... regions)
5933    {
5934        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0)
5935            return new int[0][0];
5936        int w = regions[0].width, h = regions[0].height, l = regions.length, ys = regions[0].ySections;
5937        int[][] numbers = new int[w][h];
5938        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
5939            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
5940                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
5941                    numbers[x][y] += (regions[i].data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 : 0;
5942                }
5943            }
5944        }
5945        return numbers;
5946    }

5948    /**
5949     * Generates a 2D int array from a List of GreasedRegions, starting at all 0 and adding 1 to the int at
5950     * a position once for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on." This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
5951     * this method, it can produce any number between 0 and 8 in a cell; if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
5952     * produce any number between 0 and 16 in a cell.
5953     * @param regions a List of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
5954     * @return a 2D int array with the same width and height as the regions, where an int cell equals the number of given GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
5955     */
5956    public static int[][] sum(List<GreasedRegion> regions)
5957    {
5958        if(regions == null || regions.isEmpty())
5959            return new int[0][0];
5960        GreasedRegion t = regions.get(0);
5961        int w = t.width, h = t.height, l = regions.size(), ys = t.ySections;
5962        int[][] numbers = new int[w][h];
5963        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
5964            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
5965                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
5966                    numbers[x][y] += (regions.get(i).data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 : 0;
5967                }
5968            }
5969        }
5970        return numbers;
5971    }

6022    /**
6023     * Generates a 2D int array from an array of GreasedRegions and an array of weights, starting the 2D result at all 0
6024     * and, for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on," adding the int in the corresponding weights array at
6025     * the position of that cell. This means if you give an array of 4 GreasedRegions to this method along with the
6026     * weights {@code 1, 2, 3, 4}, it can produce a number between 0 and 10 in a cell (where 10 is used when all 4
6027     * GreasedRegions have a cell "on," since {@code 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 == 10}); if the weights are instead
6028     * {@code 1, 10, 100, 1000}, then the results can vary between 0 and 1111, where 1111 is only if all GreasedRegions
6029     * have a cell as "on." The weights array must have a length at least equal to the length of the regions array.
6030     * @param regions an array of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6031     * @param weights an array of ints; must have length at least equal to regions' length
6032     * @return a 2D int array with the same width and height as the regions, where an int cell equals the sum of the weights corresponding to GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6033     */
6034    public static int[][] sumWeighted(GreasedRegion[] regions, int[] weights)
6035    {
6036        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0 || weights == null || weights.length < regions.length)
6037            return new int[0][0];
6038        int w = regions[0].width, h = regions[0].height, l = regions.length, ys = regions[0].ySections;
6039        int[][] numbers = new int[w][h];
6040        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6041            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6042                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6043                    numbers[x][y] += (regions[i].data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? weights[i] : 0;
6044                }
6045            }
6046        }
6047        return numbers;
6048    }

6050    /**
6051     * Generates a 2D double array from an array of GreasedRegions and an array of weights, starting the 2D result at
6052     * all 0 and, for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on," adding the double in the corresponding weights
6053     * array at the position of that cell. This means if you give an array of 4 GreasedRegions to this method along with
6054     * the weights {@code 1, 2, 3, 4}, it can produce a number between 0 and 10 in a cell (where 10 is used when all 4
6055     * GreasedRegions have a cell "on," since {@code 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 == 10}); if the weights are instead
6056     * {@code 1, 10, 100, 1000}, then the results can vary between 0 and 1111, where 1111 is only if all GreasedRegions
6057     * have a cell as "on." The weights array must have a length at least equal to the length of the regions array.
6058     * @param regions an array of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6059     * @param weights an array of doubles; must have length at least equal to regions' length
6060     * @return a 2D double array with the same width and height as the regions, where an double cell equals the sum of the weights corresponding to GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6061     */
6062    public static double[][] sumWeightedDouble(GreasedRegion[] regions, double[] weights)
6063    {
6064        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0 || weights == null || weights.length < regions.length)
6065            return new double[0][0];
6066        int w = regions[0].width, h = regions[0].height, l = regions.length, ys = regions[0].ySections;
6067        double[][] numbers = new double[w][h];
6068        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6069            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6070                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6071                    numbers[x][y] += (regions[i].data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? weights[i] : 0.0;
6072                }
6073            }
6074        }
6075        return numbers;
6076    }

6078    /**
6079     * Adds to an existing 2D int array with an array or vararg of GreasedRegions, adding 1 to the int in existing at
6080     * a position once for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on." This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
6081     * this method, it can increment by any number between 0 and 8 in a cell; if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
6082     * increase the value in existing by any number between 0 and 16 in a cell.
6083     * @param existing a non-null 2D int array that will have each cell incremented by the sum of the GreasedRegions
6084     * @param regions an array or vararg of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6085     * @return existing, after modification, where an int cell will be changed by the number of given GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6086     */
6087    public static int[][] sumInto(int[][] existing, GreasedRegion... regions)
6088    {
6089        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0 || existing == null || existing.length == 0 || existing[0].length == 0)
6090            return existing;
6091        int w = existing.length, h = existing[0].length, l = regions.length, ys;
6092        for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6093            GreasedRegion region = regions[i];
6094            ys = region.ySections;
6095            for (int x = 0; x < w && x < region.width; x++) {
6096                for (int y = 0; y < h && y < region.height; y++) {
6097                    existing[x][y] += (region.data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 : 0;
6098                }
6099            }
6100        }
6101        return existing;
6102    }

6105    /**
6106     * Adds to an existing 2D double array with an array or vararg of GreasedRegions, adding 1 to the double in existing
6107     * at a position once for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on." This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
6108     * this method, it can increment by any number between 0 and 8 in a cell; if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
6109     * increase the value in existing by any number between 0 and 16 in a cell.
6110     * @param existing a non-null 2D double array that will have each cell incremented by the sum of the GreasedRegions
6111     * @param regions an array or vararg of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6112     * @return existing, after modification, where a double cell will be changed by the number of given GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6113     */
6114    public static double[][] sumIntoDouble(double[][] existing, GreasedRegion... regions)
6115    {
6116        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0 || existing == null || existing.length == 0 || existing[0].length == 0)
6117            return existing;
6118        int w = existing.length, h = existing[0].length, l = regions.length, ys = regions[0].ySections;
6119        for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6120            for (int x = 0; x < w && x < regions[i].width; x++) {
6121                for (int y = 0; y < h && y < regions[i].height; y++) {
6122                    existing[x][y] += (regions[i].data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1.0 : 0.0;
6123                }
6124            }
6125        }
6126        return existing;
6127    }

6129    /**
6130     * Discouraged from active use; slower than {@link squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap} and has less features.
6131     * @param map a 2D char array where '#' is a wall
6132     * @param goals an array or vararg of Coord to get the distances toward
6133     * @return a 2D double array of distances from a cell to the nearest goal
6134     */
6135    public static double[][] dijkstraScan(char[][] map, Coord... goals)
6136    {
6137        if(map == null || map.length <= 0 || map[0].length <= 0 || goals == null || goals.length <= 0)
6138            return new double[0][0];
6139        int w = map.length, h = map[0].length, ys = (h + 63) >>> 6;
6140        double[][] numbers = new double[w][h];
6141        GreasedRegion walls = new GreasedRegion(map, '#'), floors = new GreasedRegion(walls).not(),
6142                middle = new GreasedRegion(w, h, goals).and(floors);
6143        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> regions = middle.floodSeriesToLimit(floors);
6144        int l = regions.size();
6145        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6146            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6147                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6148                    numbers[x][y] += (regions.get(i).data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 : 0;
6149                }
6150            }
6151        }
6152        return numbers;
6153    }

6164        int w = map.length, h = map[0].length, ys = (h + 63) >>> 6;

6167                middle = new GreasedRegion(w, h, goals).and(floors);
6168        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> regions = middle.floodSeriesToLimit8way(floors);

6174                }

6180    /**
6181     * Generates a 2D int array from an array or vararg of GreasedRegions, treating each cell in the nth region as the
6182     * nth bit of the int at the corresponding x,y cell in the int array. This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
6183     * this method, it can produce any 8-bit number in a cell (0-255); if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
6184     * produce any 16-bit number (0-65535).
6185     * @param regions an array or vararg of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6186     * @return a 2D int array with the same width and height as the regions, with bits per int taken from the regions
6187     */
6188    public static int[][] bitSum(GreasedRegion... regions)
6189    {
6190        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0)
6191            return new int[0][0];
6192        int w = regions[0].width, h = regions[0].height, l = Math.min(32, regions.length), ys = regions[0].ySections;
6193        int[][] numbers = new int[w][h];
6194        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6195            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6196                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6197                    numbers[x][y] |= (regions[i].data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 << i : 0;
6198                }
6199            }
6200        }
6201        return numbers;
6202    }

6270    /**
6271     * Computes a 64-bit hash code of this GreasedRegion given a 64-bit seed; even if given two very similar seeds,
6272     * this should produce very different hash codes for the same GreasedRegion.
6273     * <br>
6274     * Meant for potential use in Bloom filters. Uses {@link CrossHash.Yolk}'s algorithm(s).
6275     * @param seed a seed that will determine how the hashing algorithm works; all 64 bits are used.
6276     * @return a 64-bit hash code for this GreasedRegion
6277     */
6278    public long hash64(long seed)
6279    {
6280        seed += b1;
6281        seed ^= seed >>> 23 ^ seed >>> 48 ^ seed << 7 ^ seed << 53;
6282        long a = seed + b4, b = seed + b3, c = seed + b2, d = seed + b1;
6283        final int len = data.length;
6284        for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
6285            a ^= data[i-3] * b1; a = (a << 23 | a >>> 41) * b3;
6286            b ^= data[i-2] * b2; b = (b << 25 | b >>> 39) * b4;
6287            c ^= data[i-1] * b3; c = (c << 29 | c >>> 35) * b5;
6288            d ^= data[i  ] * b4; d = (d << 31 | d >>> 33) * b1;
6289            seed += a + b + c + d;
6290        }
6291        seed += b5;
6292        switch (len & 3) {
6293            case 1: seed = wow(seed, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
6294            case 2: seed = wow(seed + data[len-2], b2 + data[len-1]); break;
6295            case 3: seed = wow(seed + data[len-3], b2 + data[len-2]) ^ wow(seed + data[len-1], seed ^ b3); break;
6296        }
6297        seed = wow(seed + height, b4 + width);
6298        seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0 ^ seed >>> 32);
6299        return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
6300
6301    }

6303    public String serializeToString()
6304    {
6305        return width +
6306                "," + height +
6307                "," + StringKit.joinAlt(",",data);
6308    }
6309    public static GreasedRegion deserializeFromString(String s)
6310    {
6311        if(s == null || s.isEmpty())
6312            return null;
6313        int gap = s.indexOf(','), w = Integer.parseInt(s.substring(0, gap)),
6314                gap2 = s.indexOf(',', gap+1), h = Integer.parseInt(s.substring(gap+1, gap2));
6315        String[] splits = StringKit.split(s.substring(gap2+1), ",");
6316        long[] data = new long[splits.length];
6317        for (int i = 0; i < splits.length; i++) {
6318            data[i] = StringKit.longFromDec(splits[i]);
6319        }
6320        return new GreasedRegion(data, w, h);
6321    }

6336    public String toCompressedString()
6337    {
6338        if(height > 0x4000)
6339            throw new UnsupportedOperationException("Height is too large to compress, aborting.");
6340        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(width * height >> 2);
6341        boolean on = false;
6342        int span = 0;
6343        char adjust = (char) nextPowerOfTwo(Math.max(height, 32));
6344        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6345            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
6346                if(((data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) == 0) == on)
6347                    span++;
6348                else
6349                {
6350                    on = !on;
6351                    sb.append((char)(adjust | span));
6352                    span = 1;
6353                }
6354            }
6355            if(on)
6356            {
6357                sb.append((char)(adjust | span));
6358            }
6359            sb.append('\n');
6360            on = false;
6361            span = 0;
6362        }
6363        return sb.toString();
6364    }

6463    /**
6464     * Randomly removes points from a GreasedRegion, with larger values for preservation keeping more of the existing
6465     * shape intact. If preservation is 1, roughly 1/2 of all points will be removed; if 2, roughly 1/4, if 3, roughly
6466     * 1/8, and so on, so that preservation can be thought of as a negative exponent of 2.
6467     * @param rng used to determine random factors
6468     * @param preservation roughly what degree of points to remove (higher keeps more); removes about {@code 1/(2^preservation)} points
6469     * @return a randomly modified change to this GreasedRegion
6470     */
6471    public GreasedRegion deteriorate(RandomnessSource rng, int preservation) {
6472        if(rng == null || width <= 2 || ySections <= 0 || preservation <= 0)
6473            return this;
6474        long mash;
6475        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
6476            mash = rng.nextLong();
6477            for (int j = i; j < preservation; j++) {
6478                mash |= rng.nextLong();
6479            }
6480            data[i] &= mash;
6481        }
6482        tallied = false;
6483        return this;
6484    }
6485
6486    /**
6487     * Randomly removes points from a GreasedRegion, with preservation as a fraction between 1.0 (keep all) and 0.0
6488     * (remove all). If preservation is 0.5, roughly 1/2 of all points will be removed; if 0.25, roughly 3/4 will be
6489     * removed (roughly 0.25 will be _kept_), if 0.8, roughly 1/5 will be removed (and about 0.8 will be kept), and so
6490     * on. Preservation must be between 0.0 and 1.0 for this to have the intended behavior; 1.0 or higher will keep all
6491     * points without change (returning this GreasedRegion), while anything less than 0.015625 (1.0/64) will empty this
6492     * GreasedRegion (using {@link #empty()}) and then return it. The parameter {@code random} can be an object like a
6493     * {@link DiverRNG}, an {@link RNG} backed by a well-distributed RandomnessSource like its default, DiverRNG, a
6494     * {@link GWTRNG} (especially if you target GWT, where it will perform much better than most alternatives), or any
6495     * of various other RandomnessSource implementations that distribute bits well for
6496     * {@link RandomnessSource#nextLong()}, but should not be intentionally-biased RNGs like {@link DharmaRNG} or 
6497     * {@link EditRNG}, nor double-based QRNGs like {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} or {@link SobolQRNG}.
6498     * @param random used to determine random factors; likely to be an {@link RNG}, {@link DiverRNG}, or {@link GWTRNG}
6499     * @param preservation the rough fraction of points to keep, between 0.0 and 1.0
6500     * @return a randomly modified change to this GreasedRegion
6501     */
6502    public GreasedRegion deteriorate(final RandomnessSource random, final double preservation) {
6503        if(random == null || width <= 2 || ySections <= 0 || preservation >= 1)
6504            return this;
6505        if(preservation <= 0)
6506            return empty();
6507        int bitCount = (int) (preservation * 64);
6508        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
6509            data[i] &= approximateBits(random, bitCount);
6510        }
6511        tallied = false;
6512        return this;
6513    }
6514
6515    /**
6516     * Inverts the on/off state of the cell with the given x and y.
6517     * @param x the x position of the cell to flip
6518     * @param y the y position of the cell to flip
6519     * @return this for chaining, modified
6520     */
6521    public GreasedRegion flip(int x, int y) {
6522        if(x >= 0 && y >= 0 && x < width && y < height && ySections > 0)
6523        {
6524            data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] ^= (1L << (y & 63));
6525            tallied = false;
6526        }
6527        return this;
6528
6529    }

6531    /**
6532     * Returns a new GreasedRegion that has been mirrored along the rightmost edge, parallel to the y-axis. The new
6533     * GreasedRegion will have exactly twice the width, the additional width will have the contents of the original
6534     * GreasesRegion in reversed order. The positions shared by both GreasedRegions will be the same, that is, any area
6535     * not added to the original will be equal to the original.
6536     * @return a new GreasedRegion with twice the width of {@code this}, that is mirrored along the rightmost edge
6537     */
6538    public GreasedRegion mirrorY()
6539    {
6540        GreasedRegion next = new GreasedRegion(data, width, height, width * 2, height);
6541        for (int i = 0, o = width * 2 - 1; i < width; i++, o--) {
6542            System.arraycopy(data, ySections * i, next.data, ySections * o, ySections);
6543        }
6544        return next;
6545    }

6547    @Override
6548    public boolean intersectsWith(Zone other) {
6549        if (other instanceof GreasedRegion)
6550            return intersects((GreasedRegion) other);
6551        long t, w;
6552        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6553            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6554                if ((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0) {
6555                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6556                    while (w != 0) {
6557                        if (other.contains(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w)))
6558                            return true;
6559                        t ^= w;
6560                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6561                    }
6562                }
6563            }
6564        }
6565        return false;
6566    }

6597     * @return A new GreasedRegion where "off" cells adjacent to {@code this}

6606    /**
6607     * Checks if {@code c} is present in this GreasedRegion. Returns true if and only if c is present in this
6608     * GreasedRegion as an "on" cell. This will never be true if c is null, has negative x or y, has a value for x that
6609     * is equal to or greater than {@link #width}, or has a value for y that is equal to or greater than
6610     * {@link #height}, but none of those conditions will cause Exceptions to be thrown.
6611     * @param c a Coord to try to find in this GreasedRegion; if null this will always return false
6612     * @return true if {@code c} is an "on" cell in this GreasedRegion, or false otherwise, including if c is null
6613     */
6614    @Override
6615    public boolean contains(Coord c) {
6616        return c != null && contains(c.x, c.y);
6617    }
6618
6619    /**
6620     * Checks whether all Coords in {@code other} are also present in {@code this}.
6621     * Requires that {@code other} won't give a null Coord while this method iterates over it.
6622     * @param other another Zone, such as a GreasedRegion or a {@link squidpony.squidgrid.zone.CoordPackerZone}
6623     * @return true if all Coords in other are "on" in this GreasedRegion, or false otherwise
6624     */
6625    @Override
6626    public boolean contains(Zone other) {
6627        if(other instanceof Collection)
6628            return containsAll((Collection) other);
6629        for(Coord c : other)
6630        {
6631            if(!contains(c.x, c.y))
6632                return false;
6633        }
6634        return true;
6635    }
6636
6637    /**
6638     * @param smallestOrBiggest if true, finds the smallest x-coordinate value;
6639     *                          if false, finds the biggest.
6640     * @return The x-coordinate of the Coord within {@code this} that has the
6641     * smallest (or biggest) x-coordinate. Or -1 if the zone is empty.
6642     */
6643    @Override
6644    public int x(boolean smallestOrBiggest) {
6645        if(smallestOrBiggest)
6646            return first().x;
6647        else
6648            return nth(size()-1).x;
6649    }
6650
6651    /**
6652     * @param smallestOrBiggest if true, finds the smallest y-coordinate value;
6653     *                          if false, finds the biggest.
6654     * @return The y-coordinate of the Coord within {@code this} that has the
6655     * smallest (or biggest) y-coordinate. Or -1 if the zone is empty.
6656     */
6657    @Override
6658    public int y(boolean smallestOrBiggest) {
6659        long t, w;
6660        if(smallestOrBiggest) {
6661            int best = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
6662            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6663                for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6664                    if ((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0) {
6665                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6666                        while (w != 0) {
6667                            best = Math.min(s << 6 | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w), best);
6668                            if(best == 0)
6669                                return 0;
6670                            t ^= w;
6671                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6672                        }
6673                    }
6674                }
6675            }
6676            return best == Integer.MAX_VALUE ? -1 : best;
6677        }
6678        else
6679        {
6680            int best = -1;
6681            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6682                for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6683                    if ((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0) {
6684                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6685                        while (w != 0) {
6686                            best = Math.max(s << 6 | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w), best);
6687                            if(best == height - 1)
6688                                return best;
6689                            t ^= w;
6690                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6691                        }
6692                    }
6693                }
6694            }
6695            return best;
6696        }
6697    }
6698
6699    /**
6700     * Gets the distance between the minimum x-value contained in this GreasedRegion and the maximum x-value in it.
6701     * Not the same as accessing the field {@link #width} on a GreasedRegion! The field will get the span of the space
6702     * that the GreasedRegion can use, including "on" and "off" cells. This method will only get the distance between
6703     * the furthest-separated "on" cells on the x-axis, and won't consider "off" cells. This method can return -1 if the
6704     * GreasedRegion is empty, 0 if the "on" cells are all in a vertical line (that is, when the minimum x is equal to
6705     * the maximum x), or a positive int in other cases with multiple x-values.
6706     * @return the distance on the x-axis between the "on" cell with the lowest x-value and the one with the highest
6707     */
6708    @Override
6709    public int getWidth() {
6710        if (super.width == -2)
6711            super.width = isEmpty() ? -1 : x(false) - x(true);
6712        return super.width;
6713    }
6714    /**
6715     * Gets the distance between the minimum y-value contained in this GreasedRegion and the maximum y-value in it.
6716     * Not the same as accessing the field {@link #height} on a GreasedRegion! The field will get the span of the space
6717     * that the GreasedRegion can use, including "on" and "off" cells. This method will only get the distance between
6718     * the furthest-separated "on" cells on the y-axis, and won't consider "off" cells. This method can return -1 if the
6719     * GreasedRegion is empty, 0 if the "on" cells are all in a horizontal line (that is, when the minimum y is equal to
6720     * the maximum y), or a positive int in other cases with multiple y-values.
6721     * @return the distance on the y-axis between the "on" cell with the lowest y-value and the one with the highest
6722     */
6723    @Override
6724    public int getHeight() {
6725        if (super.height == -2)
6726            super.height = isEmpty() ? -1 : y(false) - y(true);
6727        return super.height;
6728    }
6729
6730    /**
6731     * Gets the diagonal distance from the point combining the lowest x-value present in this GreasedRegion with the
6732     * lowest y-value in this, to the point combining the highest x-value and the highest y-value. These minimum and
6733     * maximum values don't necessarily match a single "on" cell for each min and max corner, and can take their x and y
6734     * values from two different points. The diagonal distance uses Euclidean measurement (basic Pythagorean Theorem
6735     * math here), and will be a double.
6736     * @return the diagonal distance from (min x, min y) to (max x, max y), as a double
6737     */
6738    @Override
6739    public double getDiagonal() {
6740        final int w = getWidth();
6741        final int h = getHeight();
6742        return Math.sqrt((w * w) + (h * h));
6743    }

6747//        return super.getCenter();
6748//    }
6749
6750    @Override
6751    public GreasedRegion getInternalBorder() {
6752        return copy().surface8way();
6753    }

6755    /**
6756     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a deterministic but random-seeming
6757     * scattering of chosen cells with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
6758     * in this. This is pseudo-random with the given seed (which will be made into an odd number if it is not one
6759     * already), and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, and
6760     * much faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but
6761     * a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in testing. Restricts the total size of the returned array to
6762     * a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the
6763     * size.
6764     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
6765     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
6766     * @param seed a long seed to change the points; the most significant 21 bits (except the sign bit) and least significant bit are ignored
6767     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the pseudo-random cells
6768     */
6769    public Coord[] mixedRandomSeparatedAlt(double fraction, int limit, long seed)
6770    {
6771        if(fraction < 0)
6772            return new Coord[0];
6773        if(fraction > 1)
6774            fraction = 1;
6775        int tmp, ic;
6776        long t, w;
6777        seed |= 1L;
6778        final int total = size();
6779        int ct = (int)(total * fraction);
6780        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
6781            ct = limit;
6782        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
6783        EACH_QUASI:
6784        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
6785        {
6786            tmp = (int)(VanDerCorputQRNG.altDetermine(seed, i+1) * total);
6787
6788            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6789                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6790                    if ((ic = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
6791                        t = data[x * ySections + s];
6792                        for (--ic; t != 0; ic--) {
6793                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6794                            if (ic == tmp)
6795                            {
6796                                vl[i] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.bitCount(w-1));
6797                                continue EACH_QUASI;
6798                            }
6799                            t ^= w;
6800                        }
6801                    }
6802                }
6803            }
6804        }
6805        return vl;
6806    }
6807

6809    public class GRIterator implements Iterator<Coord>
6810    {
6811        public int index = 0;
6812        private long t, w;
6813        public GRIterator()
6814        {
6815            if(!tallied)
6816                tally();
6817        }
6818        @Override
6819        public boolean hasNext() {
6820            return index < ct;
6821        }
6822
6823        @Override
6824        public Coord next() {
6825            int c;
6826            if(index >= ct)
6827                return null;
6828            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6829                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6830                    if ((c = counts[x * ySections + s]) > index) {
6831                        t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
6832                        for (--c; t != 0; c--) {
6833                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6834                            if (c == index)
6835                            {
6836                                index++;
6837                                return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.bitCount(w-1));
6838                            }
6839                            t ^= w;
6840                        }
6841                    }
6842                }
6843            }
6844            return null;
6845
6846            /*
6847            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6848                for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6849                    if ((w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(data[x * ySections + s])) != 0 && i++ >= index) {
6850                        if(index++ < limit)
6851                            return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
6852                        else
6853                            return null;
6854                    }
6855                }
6856            }
6857            */
6858        }
6859
6860        @Override
6861        public void remove() {
6862            throw new UnsupportedOperationException("remove() is not supported on this Iterator.");
6863        }
6864    }
